|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727032939/http://www.khou.com/news/crime/Two-suspects-charged-with-capital-murder-in-Air-Jordans-robbery-185158251.html |archivedate=2013-07-27 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pix11.com/2016/02/12/brooklyn-teen-tries-to-steal-air-jordans-loses-arm-in-craigslist-robbery-gone-wrong-police/|title=Brooklyn teen tries to steal Air Jordans, loses arm in Craigslist robbery gone wrong: police|last=Brito|first=Chris|date=12 February 2016|work=Pix 11|access-date=26 April 2017}}</ref> such as the murder of a 15-year-old high school student named Michael Eugene Thomas who was choked to death by one of his peers for a pair of Air Jordan sneakers in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rick Telander |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1136895/index.htm |title=In America's cities, kids are killing kids over sneakers – 05.14.90 – SI Vault |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=1990-05-14 |accessdate=2013-04-23}}</ref>
In 1988, the then-principal of [[Mumford High School]] in Detroit mentioned that clothing-related violence had reached a point where he felt it was necessary to ban certain items of clothing, including the Air Jordan sneaker, from the school grounds.<ref>{{cite web |author=Tom Hundley |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-04-03/news/8803050777_1_air-jordans-dress-code-troop |title=School Puts `In` Clothes On Notice |work=Chicago Tribune |date=1988-04-03 |accessdate=2013-04-23}}</ref> This ban was the first of many dress codes implemented in schools after the wave of robberies, beatings, and shootings over possession of Air Jordan sneakers and other items of clothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://petermarina.com/DOCUMENTS/JYS.pdf |format=pdf |title=Cultural meaning and hip-hop fashion in the African-American male youth subculture of New Orleans |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2013-05-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120906230836/http://petermarina.com/DOCUMENTS/JYS.pdf |archivedate=2012-09-06 }}</ref>
===Manufacturing=== [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] owns none of the factories where Air Jordans are produced and contracts the work to various factory owners. Company officials say that they only design and market the shoes. However, Nike dictates production terms and standards to the contractor, often without questioning labor or safety practices. In April 1997, 10,000 Indonesian workers went on strike over wage violations at an Air Jordan factory. The same month in Vietnam 1,300 workers went on strike demanding a 1-cent-per-hour raise, and a year later in 1998, 3,000 workers in China went on strike to protest hazardous working conditions and low wages cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalexchange.org/sweatfree/nike/faq|title=Nike FAQs - Global Exchange|publisher=|accessdate=8 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026223516/http://www.globalexchange.org/sweatfree/nike/faq|archivedate=26 October 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Sponsorship== ===Football=== In September 2018, French [[association football|football]] team, [[Paris St. Germain]], unveiled a third kit featuring the Air Jordan logo on chest. This model was designed to be worn only in the [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]].<ref>[https://www.mundodeportivo.com/futbol/internacional/20180913/451789732829/michael-jordan-se-cuela-en-la-camiseta-del-psg.html Michael Jordan se cuela en la camiseta del PSG] on Mundo Deportivo, 13 Sep 2018</ref><ref>[http://espndeportes.espn.com/futbol/francia/nota/_/id/4752221/paris-saint-germain-pone-a-michael-jordan-en-su-logo Paris Saint Germain pone a Michael Jordan en su logo], ESPN, 13 Sep 2018</ref>
===American Football=== Starting in 2016, Air Jordan became the sole equipment provider for the [[University of Michigan]] football team. <ref>[https://www.mlive.com/wolverines/index.ssf/2015/08/michael_jordan_welcomes_michig.html Michael Jordan welcomes Michigan as first ever Jordan Brand football client] on mlive.com, 13 Aug 2015 </ref> This marked the brand's first venture into a sport besides basketball. As of 2018, Air Jordan is also the equipment provider for the [[University of North Carolina]], [[University of Oklahoma]], and [[University of Florida]] football programs.<ref> [https://www.cbssports.com/college-football/news/florida-makes-big-move-joining-jordan-brands-growing-college-football-footprint/ Florida makes big move joining Jordan brand's growing college football footprint] on CBSSports.com, 6 Dec 2017</ref>
===Motorsports=== Air Jordan is an associate sponsor for [[Denny Hamlin]], driver of the #11 [[FedEx]] [[Toyota Camry]], in the [[NASCAR Monster Energy Cup Series]].<ref>[https://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Closing-Bell/2011/02/10/Denny-Hamlin.aspx Nike's Jordan Brand Agrees To Sponsor NASCAR Driver Denny Hamlin] on sportsbusinessdaily.com, 10 Feb 2011 </ref> In 2013, Air Jordan sponsored Hamlin's #51 [[Toyota Tundra]] for one race at [[Martinsville Speedway]].<ref> [https://www.foxsports.com/nascar/shake-and-bake/story/denny-hamlin-michael-jordan-partner-for-unique-nascar-sponsorship-102613 Denny Hamlin, Michael Jordan partner for unique NASCAR sponsorship] on FOXSports.com, 26 Oct 2013 </ref>

{{for|the old stadium|Verdão}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Arena Pantanal | nickname = | image = File:Cuiaba_Arena.jpg | fullname = Arena Pantanal | location = Rua Tracaia, [[Cuiabá]], [[Mato Grosso]], [[Brazil]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = May 2010 | opened = 2 April 2014 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = [[Brazilian real|R$]] 646 million
([[united states dollar|USD $]] 293 million) | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants =
[[Cuiabá Esporte Clube|Cuiabá]]
[[Mixto Esporte Clube|Mixto]] | suites = 97 | seating_capacity = 41,390,http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/bra/arena_pantanalhttp://www.stadiumguide.com/arenapantanal/ | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} '''Arena Pantanal''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Cuiabá]], [[Brazil]]. Completed on 26 April 2014, it is used mostly for [[Association football|football]] and hosted four group stage matches during the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://nz.sports.yahoo.com/news/article/-/22340876/unfinished-brazil-stadium-opens/ |title=Unfinished Brazil stadium opens |last1=Azzoni |first1=Tales |date=April 3, 2014 |website=sports.yahoo.com |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407104657/http://nz.sports.yahoo.com/news/article/-/22340876/unfinished-brazil-stadium-opens/ |archivedate=April 7, 2014 }} During the World Cup, the arena had a capacity of 41,390, and currently can seat 44,003 spectators. Prior to its use for the 2014 FIFA World Cup, the venue received much criticism. It suffered a fire in October 2013, due to [[polystyrene]] insulation panels catching alight. Although nobody was injured, the fire came within 24 hours of the state governor of [[Mato Grosso]] warning that it may not be finished for the World Cup.{{cite web|last1=Tony Jimenez|first1=Andrew|title=Soccer-Cuiaba fire adds to Brazil's World Cup woes|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/soccer-cuiaba-fire-adds-brazils-world-cup-woes-205257620--sow.html|publisher=Yahoo|agency=Reuters|date=25 October 2013|accessdate=29 June 2014}} On the day of {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = BAR | NOCname = [[Barbados Olympic Association]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 2012 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.olympic.org.bb }} | location = [[London]] | competitors = 6 | sports = 3 | flagbearer = [[Ryan Brathwaite]] (opening)
[[Kyle Maxwell]] (closing) | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = {{flagIOC|BWI|1960 Summer}} (1960) }} '''[[Barbados]]''' competed at the '''[[2012 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] from 27 July to 12 August 2012. This nation marked its eleventh appearance at the Olympic games. The [[Barbados Olympic Association]] sent the nation's smallest team to the Games. A total of six athletes, all men, participate only in athletics, judo, and swimming. The nation's female athletes, however, failed to compete for the first time in its history since its national debut at the [[1968 Summer Olympics]] in Mexico City. The Barbadian team also included backstroke and medley swimmer [[Bradley Ally]], who competed at his third Olympic games. Sprint hurdler [[Ryan Brathwaite]] was appointed by the committee to be the nation's flag bearer at the opening ceremony. Barbados left London, however, without winning a single Olympic medal for the third consecutive time. Brathwaite, the nation's Olympic hopeful, nearly missed out of the medal standings, finishing abruptly in fifth place. ==Athletics== {{main|Athletics at the 2012 Summer Olympics}} Athletes from Barbados have so far achieved qualifying standards in the following athletics events (up to a maximum of 3 athletes in each event at the 'A' Standard, and 1 at the 'B' Standard):{{cite {{other people}} {{Infobox NFL player |name = Ben Davidson |image = Ben Davidson.jpg |image_size = 230 |alt = |caption = 1960 Washington Huskies yearbook |number = 72, 75, 83 |position = [[Defensive end]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1940|6|14|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. |death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|7|2|1940|6|14|mf=y}} |death_place = [[San Diego]], [[California]], U.S. |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 8 |weight_lbs = 275 |high_school = [[Woodrow Wilson High School (Los Angeles)|Los Angeles (CA)
Woodrow Wilson]] |college = [[1960 Washington Huskies football team|Washington]]
[[East Los Angeles College]] [[Community colleges in the United States|(JC)]] |draftyear = 1961 |draftround = [[1961 NFL draft#Round four|4]] |draftpick = 46 |afldraftyear = |afldraftround = |afldraftpick = |undraftedyear = |pastteams = * [[Green Bay Packers]] ({{NFL Year|1961}}) * [[Washington Redskins]] ({{NFL Year|1962}}–{{NFL Year|1963}}) * [[Oakland Raiders]] ([[1964 American Football League season|1964]]–{{NFL Year|1971}}) * [[Portland Storm]] ([[1974 WFL season|1974]]) |highlights = * 3× [[American Football League All-Star game|AFL All-Star]] (1966, 1967, 1968) * [[History of the National Football League championship|NFL champion]] ([[1961 NFL Championship Game|1961]]) * [[American Football League#AFL Championship Games|AFL champion]] ([[1967 American Football League Championship Game|1967]]) |nfl = 2512496 |pfr = DaviBe00 }} '''Benjamin Earl Franklin "Ben" Davidson, Jr.''' (June 14, 1940 – July 2, 2012) was an [[American football]] player, a defensive end best known for his play with the [[Oakland Raiders]] in the [[American Football League]]. Earlier in his career, he was with the [[Green Bay Packers]] and [[Washington Redskins]] of the [[National Football League]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/04/sports/football/ben-davidson-defensive-end-dies-at-72.html |newspaper=New York Times |agency=Associated Press |title=Ben Davidson, defensive end, dies at 72 |date=July 3, 2012 |accessdate=February 27, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Dillman |first=Lisa |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-ben-davidson-20120704,0,7541335.story |title=Ben Davidson dies at 72; Oakland Raider, fixture in beer commercials |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=July 4, 2012 |accessdate=February 27, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/25/sports/la-sp-crowe-20100726 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |last=Crowe |first=Jerry |title=For Ben Davidson, the quintessential Raider, football was the ticket to a great life |date=July 25, 2015 |accessdate=February 27, 2016}} ==Early years== Born and raised in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], Davidson was the son of Avis (née Wheat) and Benjamin Earl Franklin, Senior.{{cite web|url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/w/i/l/Tracy-Lynne-Williamson/GENE7-0004.html |title=Family Tree Maker's Genealogy Site: Genealogy Report: Descendants of Benjamin (Frank) Franklin Davidson |publisher=Familytreemaker.genealogy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}} He attended [[Woodrow Wilson High School (Los Angeles)|Woodrow Wilson High School]] in the [[El Sereno, Los Angeles|El Sereno]] neighborhood of Los Angeles, but did not play [[High school football|football in high school]]; because of his height ({{height|ft=6|in=8}}), [[High school basketball|basketball]] and track were more to his liking.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2VxWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NPADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6566%2C1114081 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Weaver |first=Dan |title=Davidson shows his Liter side |date=April 23, 1992 |page=C1}} While attending junior college at [[East Los Angeles College]], he was spotted by the football coach and asked to join the team. He was subsequently recruited to play at the [[Washington Huskies football|University of Washington]] in [[Seattle]] in [[1959 Washington Huskies football team|1959]], where he flourished as a member of [[1960 Rose Bowl|consecutive]] [[1961 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]]-winning teams under head coach [[Jim Owens]] and gained entry into professional football. ==Professional career== ===NFL=== Davidson was selected in the [[1961 NFL draft#Round four|fourth round]] of the [[1961 NFL draft]] by the [[1961 New York Giants season|New York Giants]], but was traded in training camp to the [[1961 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]].{{cite news |url=http://www.jsonline.com/packerinsider/brief-stay-leads-to-glory-131560758.html |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |last=Hendricks |first=Martin |title=Davidson's brief stay leads to glory |date=October 11, 2011 |accessdate=February 27, 2016}} As a rookie, he played mostly special teams for the Packers in [[1961 Green Bay Packers season|1961]], who beat the Giants 37–0 in the [[1961 NFL Championship Game|championship game]], the first of five NFL titles for head coach [[Vince Lombardi]].[http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-videos/09000d5d8060ece8/1961-NFL-Championship-Game 1961 NFL Championship Game at NFL.Com] During training camp in 1962, Davidson was traded to the [[1962 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] for a fifth round draft choice.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ysEVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1hAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6889%2C1177522 |newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel |last=Lea |first=Bud |title=Davidson traded to Redskins |date=August 21, 1962 |page=2, part 2}} He played there in [[1962 Washington Redskins season|1962]] and [[1963 Washington Redskins season|1963]], until he was waived in September [[1964 Washington Redskins season|1964]] final cuts after not meeting the team's strict weight guidelines.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jNhaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hWwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5196%2C1765022 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |agency=Associated |title=Barnes, five other cut by Redskins |date=September 10, 1964 |page=30 }} ===AFL=== Davidson is best remembered his play with the [[American Football League]] [[Oakland Raiders]]. [[Al Davis]] signed him as a free agent shortly after his release from the Redskins and he thrived as a pass rusher under head coaches Davis, [[John Rauch]], and [[John Madden (American football)|John Madden]]. Davidson played in Oakland from [[1964 Oakland Raiders season|1964]] through [[1972 Oakland Raiders season|1972]], and was part of the [[AFL–NFL merger|league merger]] in {{nfly|1970}}. He was an [[American Football League All-Star games|AFL All-Star]] in 1966, 1967, and 1968. The Raiders won the [[1967 American Football League Championship Game|AFL championship]] in [[1967 Oakland Raiders season|1967]] and played in [[Super Bowl II]], but were overmatched by the [[1967 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]]. Oakland advanced to the AFL title games the next two seasons but lost to the [[1968 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] in [[1968 American Football League Championship Game|1968]] and the [[1969 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] in [[1969 American Football League Championship Game|1969]], the league's last game. A stretched [[Achilles tendon]] in 1972 kept him on the sidelines that entire season.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=r6dYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3217%2C1680242 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |agency=Associated Press |title=Davidson style belies his image |date=February 6, 1973 |page=15 }} ====Dawson-Taylor incident==== On November 1, [[1970 Oakland Raiders season|1970]], the [[Super Bowl IV|defending world champion]] [[1970 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] led the Raiders 17–14 late in the fourth quarter, and a long run for a first-down by Chiefs quarterback [[Len Dawson]] apparently sealed victory for the Chiefs in the final minute when Dawson, as he lay on the ground, was speared by Davidson, who dove into Dawson with his helmet, provoking Chiefs' receiver [[Otis Taylor (American football)|Otis Taylor]] to attack Davidson. After a bench-clearing brawl, offsetting penalties were called, nullifying the first down under the rules in effect at that time. The Chiefs were obliged to punt, and the Raiders tied the game on a [[George Blanda]] field goal with eight seconds to play. Davidson's play not only cost the Chiefs a win, but Oakland won the [[AFC West]] with a season record of 8–4–2, while Kansas City finished 7–5–2 and out of the playoffs.[http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/70s/ KC Chiefs website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609052751/http://www.kcchiefs.com/history/70s/ |date=2008-06-09 }}{{cite web|author=DtchMastr |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_SdzXsUJF98#t=35s |title="Big" Ben Davidson - Oakland Raiders |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-02-07 |accessdate=2012-07-26}} After the season, the NFL changed its rules regarding personal fouls, separating those called during a play from those called after it. ===WFL=== Three years out of football, Davidson signed with the [[Portland Storm#1974 regular season|Portland Storm]] in early September 1974, already midway through the [[World Football League]]'s inaugural [[1974 World Football League season|1974]] season.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bDRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4ucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1274%2C818676 |newspaper=Eugene Register Guard |location=Oregon |title=Davidson signs Storm contract |date=September 4, 1974 |page=1B }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bzRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4ucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1733%2C1707243|newspaper=Eugene Register Guard |location=Oregon |last=Cawood |first=Neil |title=Big Ben, Roadrunner stir the Storm, 15-8 |date=September 7, 1974 |page=1B }} While with the Storm, he lived in his motor home that he drove up from California. A late season knee injury in early November ended his season and playing career.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AJ8gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jGgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1020%2C1655789 |newspaper=Lewiston Evening Journal |location=Maine |title=Storm will have to make it without Ben Davidson |date=November 9, 1974 |page=15 }} ==Entertainment career== Davidson appeared in a few films including ''[[The Black Six]]'', ''[[MASH (film)|M*A*S*H]]'', and ''[[Conan the Barbarian (1982 film)|Conan the Barbarian]]''. He portrayed Porter the Bouncer in ''[[Behind the Green Door]]'' in [[1972 in film|1972]] and a convict football player in ''[[Necessary Roughness (film)|Necessary Roughness]]'' in [[1991 in film|1991]]. Davidson played himself in [[Miller Lite]] ads featuring [[John Madden (American football)|John Madden]] and [[Rodney Dangerfield]]. He also appeared in the short lived 1976 show ''[[Ball Four (TV series)|Ball Four]]'', the 1977 pilot for ''[[Lucan (TV series)|Lucan]]'' and the 1984 TV series Goldie and the Bears. Davidson also appeared in an episode of the 1970's TV series [[Happy Days]] as a lumberjack. ==Personal life== Following his rookie season with Green Bay, Davidson took his winner's check ($5,195) from the 1961 NFL title game and bought rental property in San Diego. He began 1961 with a [[1961 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] win on January 2 and ended it with an NFL championship on December 31, and was married in between. Davidson and fellow Oakland Raider teammate [[Tom Keating (American football)|Tom Keating]] were avid motorcycle riders and completed both a ride from California to the [[Panama Canal]] and a four-month, {{convert|14000|mi|adj=on}} trip across the United States while with the Raiders.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/25/sports/la-sp-crowe-20100726 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Jerry | last=Crowe | title=For Ben Davidson, the quintessential Raider, football was the ticket to a great life | date=July 25, 2010}} Davidson died of [[prostate cancer]] at age 72. He was retired and living in San Diego and was survived by his wife Kathy, and daughters Janella, Dana, and Vicki. ==See also== *[[List of American Football League players|Other American Football League players]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Footballstats |nfl=2512496 |cfl= |afl= |espn= |cbs= |yahoo= |fox= |si= |pfr=DaviBe00 |dbf=DAVIDBEN01 |rotoworld=}} * {{IMDb name|203234}} {{1960 Washington Huskies football navbox}} {{1961 Green Bay Packers}} {{1967 Oakland Raiders}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davidson, Ben}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American football defensive linemen]] [[Category:Green Bay Packers players]] [[Category:Oakland Raiders players]] [[Category:Portland Storm players]] [[Category:Washington Huskies football players]] [[Category:Washington Redskins players]] [[Category:American Football League All-Star players]] [[Category:American Football League champions]] [[Category:Violence in sports]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Players of American football from California]] [[Category:Deaths from prostate cancer]] [[Category:American Football League players]] [[Category:American actor-athletes]]

page.title: Best Female Soccer Player ESPY Award

revision.comment: /* top */Improving links and other minor cleanup tasks using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Best Female Soccer Player [[ESPY Award]]''' was presented annually between [[2002 in sports|2002]] and [[2004 in sports|2004]] to the [[female]] [[Association football|soccer]] ([[association football]]) player adjudged to be the best in a given [[calendar year]] among those contesting the sport on the [[professional sports|professional]] or [[FIFA|international]] level. The award—and the [[Best Male Soccer Player ESPY Award]]—evolved from the [[Best Soccer Player ESPY Award]], which was awarded in [[2000 in sports|2000]] and [[2001 in sports|2001]], and the latter once more absorbed the gender-specific awards in [[2005 in sports|2005]]. During the award's three years, the voting panel comprised variously [[fan (aficionado)|fans]], who participated through [[Internet]] balloting; [[sports journalism|sportswriter]]s and [[Sports presenter|broadcasters]], sports [[corporate officer|executives]], and retired [[sportsperson]]s, termed collectively ''experts''; and [[List of ESPN personalities|ESPN personalities]]. The [[ESPY Awards#Ceremonies|ESPY Awards ceremony]] was conducted in June and awards conferred reflected performance and achievement over the twelve months previous to presentation.Because of the [[ESPY Awards#Timing|rescheduling]] of the ESPY Awards ceremony, the award presented in [[2002 in sports|2002]] was given in consideration of performance betwixt February [[2001 in sports|2001]] and June 2002. ==List of winners== {| class="wikitable" |- style="white-space: nowrap;" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Year !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Player !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|National team
represented !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Club team
represented !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Position primarily
played |- |[[2002 in sports|2002]] |[[Tiffeny Milbrett]] |{{fbw|USA|name=United States}} |[[New York Power]] |[[Striker (association football)|Forward]] |- |[[2003 in sports|2003]] |[[Kátia Cilene Teixeira da Silva|Kátia]] |{{fbw|BRA}} |[[San Jose CyberRays]] |[[Striker (association football)|Forward]] |- |[[2004 in sports|2004]] |[[Mia Hamm]] |{{fbw|USA|name=United States}} |None |[[Striker (association football)|Forward]] |- |} ==See also== *[[FIFA Women's World Cup|FIFA Women's World Cup Awards]] *[[FIFA World Player of the Year#List of female winners|FIFA World Player of the Year]] ==Notes== ==References== *{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20020223000325/http://www.hickoksports.com/history/espyawrd.shtml |title=Enumeration of past winners from HickokSports.com |date=2002-02-23}} *[http://espn.go.com/espy2004/s/04nomineesindex.html 2004 ESPY Award winners] *[http://espn.go.com/espy2003/ 2003 ESPY Award winners] *[http://espn.go.com/espy2002/s/02nomineesindex.html 2002 ESPY Award winners] {{ESPYs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best Female Soccer Player Espy Award}} [[Category:ESPY Awards]] [[Category:American soccer trophies and awards]] [[Category:Women's association football trophies and awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2000]] [[Category:Awards disestablished in 2004]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{short description|Hungarian artistic gymnast}} {{Infobox gymnast |name= Boglárka Dévai |gender= w |image= |image_size= |caption= |fullname= |altname= |nickname= |country= {{HUN}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1999|11|12}} |birth_place= |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= |discipline= WAG |level= Senior International Elite
([[Hungary women's national gymnastics team|Hungary national team]]) |natlteam= 2015 |club= |gym= |collegeteam= |headcoach= |assistcoach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals= yes |medaltemplates= {{MedalCount |[[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|European Championships]]|1|0|1 |'''Total'''|'''1'''|'''0'''|'''1''' }} {{MedalCountry|{{HUN}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|European Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2018 European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|2018 Glasgow]]|Vault}} {{MedalBronze|[[2017 European Artistic Gymnastics Championships|2017 Cluj-Napoca]]|Vault}} }} '''Boglárka Dévai''' (born {{birth date|1999|11|12|df=yes}}) is a Hungarian female [[artistic gymnast]]. She is the [[2018 European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|2018 European champion]] and [[2017 European Artistic Gymnastics Championships|2017 European bronze medalist]] on vault.{{cite web|url=https://thegymter.net/2018/08/06/2018-european-championships-results/|title=2018 European Championships Results|date=6 August 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://thegymter.net/2017/04/20/2017-european-championships-results/|title=2017 European Championships Results|date=20 April 2017|publisher=}} She participated at the [[2015 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] in Glasgow.{{cite web|title=2015 World Gymnastics Championships athletes - Boglárka Dévai|url=http://www.2015worldgymnastics.com/the-championships/athlete-profiles.aspx|work=2015worldgymnastics.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}} Dévai found international success when she won the bronze medal in the vault final at the [[2017 European Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] behind [[Coline Devillard]] and [[Ellie Downie]]. She won the event at the [[2018 European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|2018 European Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] ahead of [[Angelina Melnikova]] of Russia and [[Denisa Golgota]] of Romania after upgrading her Yurchenko half-on vault to a [[Cheng Fei|Cheng]]. In doing so, she became the first Hungarian female gymnast to win a gold medal at the European Championships since [[Adrienn Varga]] also won vault in 1998.{{cite news |title=UEG on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/UEGymnastics/status/1026116381656403970 |accessdate=6 August 2018 |work=Twitter |date=5 August 2018 |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Attila |first1=Ághassi |title=20 éve várt Eb-arany, Dévai Boglárka ugrásban szerezte |url=https://index.hu/sport/2018/08/05/devai_boglarka_eb-donto_ugras/ |accessdate=6 August 2018 |work=Index |date=5 August 2018 |language=hu}} ==References== ==External links== *https://thegymter.net/boglarka-devai/ *http://sportmonitor.info/?p=3424 *https://database.fig-gymnastics.com/public/gymnasts/biography/22888/true?backUrl=%2Fpublic%2Fresults%2Fdisplay%2F12100%3FidAgeCategory%3D4%26idCategory%3D68%23anchor_30754 *http://wats-good-gabby.tumblr.com/post/95067795423/love-from-hungarys-boglarka-devai *http://vaskarika.hu/hirek/reszletek/12299/vermes_remenyekkel_a_finale_elott-devai_boglarka_es_berki_kriszt/ *http://www.utanpotlassport.hu/tag/devai-boglarka/ *http://www.nemzetisport.hu/egyeb_egyeni/torna-vk-devai-boglarka-ezustermes-lett-ugrasban-2439135 {{DEFAULTSORT:Devai, Boglarka}} [[Category:1999 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hungarian female artistic gymnasts]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Gymnasts at the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics]] {{Footer European Artistic Gymnastics Vault Champions (Women)}} {{Hungary-sport-stub}} {{Hungary-bio-stub}}

'''[[Colombia]]''' competed at the '''[[1960 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. 16 competitors, all men, took part in 13 events in 5 sports.<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/COL/summer/1960/ |title=Colombia at the 1960 Rome Summer Games |accessdate=30 July 2014 |work=sports-reference.com}}</ref>
==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} Seven male cyclists represented Colombia in 1960.
;[[Cycling at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's individual road race|Individual road race]] * [[Rubén Darío Gómez]] * [[Hernán Medina]] * [[Ramón Hoyos]] * [[Pablo Hurtado]]
;[[Cycling at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's team time trial|Team time trial]] * [[Rubén Darío Gómez]] * [[Roberto Buitrago]] * [[Pablo Hurtado]] * [[Hernán Medina]]
;[[Cycling at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's sprint|Sprint]] * [[Mario Vanegas]]
;[[Cycling at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's 1000m time trial|1000m time trial]] * [[Diego Calero]]
==Diving== {{main|Diving at the 1960 Summer Olympics}}
==Fencing== {{main|Fencing at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} Two fencers represented Colombia in 1960.
;[[Fencing at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's foil|Men's foil]] * [[Jaime Duque]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]]
;[[Fencing at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's épée|Men's épée]] * [[Jaime Duque]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]]
;[[Fencing at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's sabre|Men's sabre]] * [[Jaime Duque]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]]
==Shooting== {{main|Shooting at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} Three shooters represented Colombia in 1960.
;[[Shooting at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre pistol|50 m pistol]] * [[Noe Balvin]] * [[Fernando Hoyos]]
;[[Shooting at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre rifle three positions|50 m rifle, three positions]] * [[José María Vallsera]]
==Weightlifting== {{main|Weightlifting at the 1960 Summer Olympics}}

[[Beira, Mozambique|Beira]], [[Mozambique]] |capacity = 6,000 |chairman = |manager = |league = [[Moçambola]] 3 |season = 2006 |position = 6 }} '''Cultural Beira''', usually known simply as '''Cultural''', is a traditional [[association football]] club based in [[Beira, Mozambique]]. They played in the [[Moçambola]], the highest level of football in Mozambique in [[1980 Campeonato Moçambicano de Futebol|1980]], finishing 7th out of 8 in the southern group.{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/moz80.html |title=Mozambique 1980 - Campeonato Nacional |last1=Todor |first1=Krastev |date=13 October 2006 |website=www.rsssf.com |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |access-date=20 July 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Beira, Mozambique]] [[Category:Football clubs in Mozambique]] {{Mozambique-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Desert Sun Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = 1280 W. Desert Sun Dr., Yuma, AZ 85365 | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1957 | opened = 1958 | renovated = 1969 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 7,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = 120 yards x 75 yards{{cite web|last1=O’Reilly|first1=Charles|title=Desert Sun Stadium, Yuma, Ariz.|url=http://mysite.verizon.net/charliesballparks/stadiums/yuma.htm|website=Charlie's Big Baseball Parks Page|accessdate=July 30, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110418083614/http://mysite.verizon.net/charliesballparks/stadiums/yuma.htm|archivedate=April 18, 2011|date=January 24, 2011}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Frontera United]] ([http://www.upslsoccer.com/ UPSL])(2015-present)
[[Arizona Strikers FC]] ([[USL W-League|W-League]])(2015)
[[Yuma Panthers (NAL)|Yuma Scorpions/Panthers]] ([[North American League (baseball)|NAL]]) (2005-2013)
[[San Diego Padres]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (Spring Training) (1969-1993)
[[Yakult Swallows]] ([[Nippon Professional Baseball|NPB]]) (Spring Training) (1979-1998) }} '''Desert Sun Stadium''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] in [[Yuma, Arizona]], originally built for [[baseball]]. It was the home field of the [[North American League (baseball)|North American League]]'s [[Yuma Scorpions]] [[minor league]] baseball team and the [[Arizona Winter League]] and [[Arizona Summer League]]. The stadium, which originally opened in 1969, serves as the main field of the [[Ray Kroc Baseball Complex]]. It was the spring training home of the [[San Diego Padres]] from 1969 until 1994. [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE Wrestling]] occasionally makes a stop at the baseball complex as well. In 2015, Desert Sun Stadium was converted to a soccer stadium by OneGoal LLC, an organization that paid for the $15,000 conversion fee.{{Cite news|first=Holly|last=Sweet|title=Yuma City Council to approve Desert Sun Stadium contract|work=[[KYMA]] [[KSWT]] [[KECY]] News|accessdate=March 12, 2015|date=March 4, 2015|url=http://www.kyma.com/yuma-city-council-to-approve-desert-sun-stadium-contract|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402140010/http://www.kyma.com/yuma-city-council-to-approve-desert-sun-stadium-contract|archive-date=April 2, 2015}} [[Frontera United]] has played at Desert Sun Stadium since 2015. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite web|title=Stadium Information: Desert Sun Stadium|url=http://www.goldenbaseball.com/winter/subcontent.aspx?SecID=945|website=[[Arizona Winter League]]|publisher=[[Golden Baseball League]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117000215/http://www.goldenbaseball.com/winter/subcontent.aspx?SecID=945|archivedate=November 17, 2010}} {{San Diego Padres}} {{Coord|32|39|47|N|114|38|11|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Yuma, Arizona]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:San Diego Padres spring training venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Yuma County, Arizona]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Arizona]] [[Category:1958 establishments in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]] {{Arizona-baseball-venue-stub}}

[[File:Dipexercise.svg|thumb|300px|frame|right|A dip bar being used to do the dip exercise.]] A '''dip bar''' is a piece of [[Physical fitness|fitness]] equipment that consists of a U-shaped bar, usually about 1" (2.5 cm) in diameter, which surrounds the user's body at the waist. It is designed for the performance of, and named after, the [[dip exercise]].
In addition to this exercise, much like the [[trap bar]] can be used for [[deadlift]]s, a dip bar has other potential uses. It can, for example, be used to do [[handstand pushup]]s, or the forearms can lie on it to be used as a (probably less comfortable) [[captain's chair]] for doing things such as [[knee raise]]s. When dip bars have clearance under the handles, they also allow the exerciser to do things like [[hip abduction]] leg raises, to work muscles like the [[gluteus medius]].
Dip bars that are high enough can also be used via having the hands below the bar instead of on top of them, using the [[finger flexor]]s to hang on. They can be used to hold the very top motion of a pull-up (generally they are not high enough to allow significant range of motion in this movement, even if the knees are bent or pulled to the chest) as well as to perform [[supine row]]s.
==See also== *[[parallettes]] *[[rings (gymnastics)]] *[[Chin-up bar]]
{{sport-equipment-stub}} [[Category:Weight training equipment]]

revision.text:
{{For|other venues with the same name|Drake Stadium (disambiguation){{!}}Drake Stadium}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Haskins Field | nickname = | image = [[File:HaskinsFieldDrakeUniversity1908.jpg|250px]] | location = | coordinates = | broke_ground = | opened = 1904 | closed = 1925 | demolished = 1925 | owner = [[Drake University]] | operator = Drake University | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Haskins Field (1904–1909) | tenants = [[Drake Bulldogs football|Drake football]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1904–1924)
[[Drake Relays]] (1910–1925) | seating_capacity = 12,000 (1925)
2,500 (1904) |}} '''Drake Stadium''' was a [[stadium]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]. Originally named '''Haskins Field''', for the son of a primary donor, stadium opened on October 8, 1904 with the University of Iowa winning 17–0 over Drake. The original name of the stadium was Haskins Field, but it was changed to Drake Stadium{{when|date=June 2017}} at the request of the Haskins.{{CN|date=June 2017}} This is not to be confused with the current [[Drake Stadium (Drake University)|Drake Stadium]] built in 1925. In 1907, renovations occurred that added seating, bringing the total to 6,700 and a drainage system was also added.{{cite web | url=http://www.godrakebulldogs.com/fls/15700/pdf/2009DrakeTrack_Low.pdf | title=2008-09 DRAKE MEN’S & WOMEN’S TRACK & FIELD/CROSS COUNTRY MEDIA GUIDE | author=Drake University | publisher=Drake University | year=2009 | accessdate=2011-01-08 | format=PDF}} Haskins Field was originally expected to be able to hold 40,000 fans if expanded to its maximum capacity.{{cite web | url=http://www.drake.edu/oncampus/vol58-no32-041706/ | title=On Campus: It adds up: Drake Stadium quantified | author=Drake University | publisher=Drake University | date=2006-04-16 | accessdate=2011-01-08 }} [[File:Drake Stadium.jpg|thumb|250px]]Subsequent additions led to a total capacity of 12,000 prior to its closure and demolition. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.drake.edu/oncampus/vol58-no32-041706/ On Campus: It adds up: Drake Stadium quantified] *[http://issuu.com/drakebulldogs12/docs/2010drakefbguide Drake football 2010 yearbook] *[http://www.godrakebulldogs.com/fls/15700/pdf/2009DrakeTrack_Low.pdf Page 26 in 2009 Drake Track guide] {{Drake Bulldogs football navbox}} [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:Drake Bulldogs football]] [[Category:Sports in Des Moines, Iowa]] [[Category:American football venues in Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1904]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Iowa]]

revision.comment: adding two sources which can be used to improve the article. Suspect the rest will have to come from local newspaper archives.
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=September 2018}}
The '''Essex Memorial Arena''' was an ice-hockey [[arena]] in [[Essex, Ontario]], Canada constructed in 1960-1961.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://windsorstar.com/news/essex-memorial-arena-demolition-under-way|title=Essex Memorial Arena demolition under way|date=2015-07-24|work=Windsor Star|access-date=2018-09-19|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://windsorstar.com/news/essex-memorial-arena-demolition-under-way|title=Essex Memorial Arena demolition under way|date=2015-07-24|work=Windsor Star|access-date=2018-09-19|language=en-US}}</ref> The capacity of the Essex Memorial Arena was 1,501 and it served as the home ice for the [[Essex 73's]] of the [[Great Lakes Junior C Hockey League]] from 1973–2009. During that time the 73's won 16 Great Lakes League Championships and 6 Ontario Junior C titles, The 2008–2009 season was to be the final year for the 73's at the Essex Memorial Arena and in that year the 73's captured the Ontario Junior C crown finishing with a perfect 31-0 record in the arena. A replacement arena was completed in September 2009. Various groups including Essex Minor Hockey continued to use the arena until it was demolished in the summer of 2015.
==History== The first records mentioning the potential of an artificial rink for Essex are from the mid-1950s. The idea grew and by March 1956 the Parks Board created an Arena Committee, which it named the ''Essex Memorial Arena Campaign Committee'', and appointed members from the Essex [[Rotary International|Rotary Club]], the [[Royal Canadian Legion|Legion (Branch 201)]], and the Kinsmen Club of Essex. The Kinsmen Club of Essex were the first to initiate a challenge to the town to raise $50,000. The name of the arena was one of the first issues addressed. It was decided that it would be called Essex Memorial Arena in honour of the men who had fought and died in [[World War I]] and [[World War II]].
==Indoor Design== The first arena proposed by the committee was an outdoor arena. An outdoor arena could only function from December 1 to April 15. The design allowed for the easy addition of a roof at a later time. The committee soon changed the original proposal from an outdoor arena to a closed arena due to the long-term economic benefit. It was $15,000 more expensive for the freezing equipment for an outdoor rink than for an indoor rink, and the utility costs for the outdoor rink would have been much higher. Another bonus to having an indoor rink was the longer skating season; 6 months compared to 4½. With 10,000 people in the area surrounding Essex the indoor option would increase revenue to easily pay for up front extra cost for an indoor arena.
==Completing the construction== The Essex community was not completely supportive of the arena building project. They feared the arena would increase water rates in town, and that the arena was an unsafe structure. By the final stages of construction funds were drying up and $100,000 would be needed to complete it. On June 19, 1961 the town went to the polls to settle the issue, voting 551 to 392 in favour of the arena loan. The loan was obtained and the building was completed within the year. The walls were made of 12" (30.5 cm) thick reinforced masonry blocks. The roof is supported by eleven trusses. The arena has heated dressing rooms, a canteen and 1054 seats. It took 937 days to fully complete the arena. The Essex Memorial Arena Campaign Committee was then dissolved and the town took control and created an Arena Commission.
The arena officially opened on November 25, 1961.
==Decommission and Demolition== In the early 2000s the deterioration of the southeast corner of the arena forced an emergency closure for repair work. This, along with the shortage of ice time in Essex Centre prompted Essex to build a new arena which was completed for the 2009-10 hockey season. Despite the completion of the new Essex Centre Sports Complex next to the Essex Memorial Arena the older structure continued to be used for hockey for a time. In August 2011 Essex and [[Lakeshore, Ontario]] agreed to keep the arena open until 2014 when Lakeshore's own new arena would be completed. With some roof repairs the arena remained open until the end of the 2014-15 hockey season. The arena was demolished in the summer of 2015.
==References== {{Reflist}}
*Essex Free Press archives *Essex Municipal Records *Kinsmen Club of Essex Archives
{{Coord|42.1683|N|82.8153|W|display=title}}

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|FIFA}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox Organization |name =International Basketball Federation (FIBA) |native_name = Fédération internationale de basket-ball |native_name_lang = fr |image = International Basketball Federation logo.svg |size = 200px |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = FIBA |motto = "We are basketball" |formation = 18 June 1932 |extinction = |type = [[List of international sports federations|Sports federation]] |location = [[Mies]], [[Switzerland]] |region_served = [[World|Worldwide]] |membership = [[List of men's national basketball teams|213 national federations]] |language = [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]]2014 ''General Statutes'' of FIBA, Article 47.1 |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Horacio Muratore]] | leader_title2 = Secretary General | leader_name2 = ''Vacant'' |key_people = [[Borislav Stanković]]
[[George Vassilakopoulos]]
[[Manfred Ströher]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.fiba.basketball}} }} The '''International Basketball Federation''', more commonly known as '''FIBA''', '''FIBA World''', or '''FIBA International''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|iː|b|ə}} {{Respell|FEE|bə}}), from its French name {{lang|fr|Fédération internationale de basket-ball}}, is an association of national organizations which governs [[international]] competition in [[basketball]]. Originally known as the {{lang|fr|Fédération internationale de basket-ball amateur}} (hence FIBA), in 1989 it dropped the word ''amateur'' from its official name but retained the acronym; the "BA" now represents the first two letters of ''basketball''. FIBA defines the international [[rules of basketball]], specifies the equipment and facilities required, regulates the transfer of athletes across countries, and controls the appointment of international [[Official (basketball)|referees]]. A total of 213 national federations are now members, organized since 1989 into five zones or "commissions": [[FIBA Africa|Africa]], [[FIBA Americas|Americas]], [[FIBA Asia|Asia]], [[FIBA Europe|Europe]], and [[FIBA Oceania|Oceania]]. The [[FIBA Basketball World Cup]] is a world tournament for men's national teams held every four years. Teams compete for the [[Naismith Trophy]], named in honor of basketball's Canadian creator [[James Naismith]]. The tournament structure is similar but not identical to that of the [[FIFA World Cup]] in football; these tournaments occurred in the same year from 1970 through 2014, but starting in [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup|2019]], the Basketball World Cup will move to the year following the FIFA World Cup. A parallel event for women's teams, the [[FIBA Women's Basketball World Cup]], is also held quadrennially; from 1986 through 2014, it was held in the same year as the men's event but in a different country. The women's tournament will continue to be held in the same year as the FIFA World Cup. In 2009 FIBA announced three new tournaments: two 12-team U-17 World Championships (one each for men and women) to be played in July 2010, and an eight-team FIBA World Club Championship to be launched in October 2010. However, the FIBA World Club Championship did not materialize. In its place, FIBA instead relaunched its original world club championship for men, the [[FIBA Intercontinental Cup]], in 2013. The newest worldwide FIBA tournaments for national teams are in the three-player half-court variation, [[3x3 (basketball)|3x3]]. The [[FIBA 3x3 U-18 World Championships]] were inaugurated in 2011, and the [[FIBA 3x3 World Championships]] for senior teams followed a year later. All events initially included separate tournaments for men's, women's, and mixed teams, but mixed championships are no longer contested. The U-18 championships, held annually, feature 32 teams in each individual tournament. The senior championships have 24 teams in each individual tournament, and are held in even-numbered years. == History == [[File:FIBALogoOld.png|thumb|150px|left|Old FIBA logo.]] [[File:World Map FIBA.svg|thumb|250px|FIBA divides the world into 5 commissions, each roughly based on a continent.]] [[File:FIBA headquarter.JPG|thumb|250px|FIBA in Mies.]] The association was founded in [[Geneva]] in 1932, two years after the sport was officially recognized by the [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]]. Its original name was {{lang|fr|Fédération internationale de basket-ball amateur}}. Eight nations were founding members: [[Argentine Basketball Federation|Argentina]], [[Czechoslovakia]], [[Greece]], [[Italian Basketball Federation|Italy]], [[Latvia]], [[Federação Portuguesa de Basquetebol|Portugal]], [[Romania]], and [[Switzerland]]. During the [[1936 Summer Olympics]] held in [[Berlin]], the Federation named [[James Naismith]] (1861–1939), the founder of [[basketball]], as its Honorary President. FIBA has organized a World Championship, now known as [[FIBA Basketball World Cup|World Cup]], for men since 1950 and a Women's World Championship, now known as the [[FIBA Women's Basketball World Cup|Women's World Cup]], since 1953. From 1986 through 2014, both events were held every four years, alternating with the [[Summer Olympic Games|Olympics]]. As noted above, the men's World Cup will be moved to a new four-year cycle, with tournaments in the year before the Summer Olympics, after 2014. The Federation headquarters moved to [[Munich]] in 1956, then returned to Geneva in 2002. In 1991, it founded the [[FIBA Hall of Fame]]; the first induction ceremony was held on 12 September 2007, during [[EuroBasket 2007]]. During its 81st anniversary in 2013, FIBA moved into its new headquarters, "The House of Basketball", at [[Mies]]. TBA is the current Secretary General of FIBA. === Presidents === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Years ! Name |- | 1932–1939 | {{flagicon|Canada}} [[James A. Naismith]] (honorary) |- | 1932–1948 | {{flagicon|Switzerland}} [[Leon Bouffard]] |- | 1948–1960 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Willard Greim]] |- | 1960–1968 | {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Antonio dos Reis Carneiro]] |- | 1968–1976 | {{flagicon|EGY}} [[Abdel Moneim Wahby]] |- | 1976–1984 | {{flagicon|PHI}} [[Gonzalo Puyat II]] |- | 1984–1990 | {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Robert Busnel]] |- | 1990–1998 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[George E.
