revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=June 2018}} The [[handball]] goalkeeper is the most defensive player of his team. His main task is to prevent the other team from scoring a goal. [[File:7m Penalty Handball.jpg|thumb|[[Thierry Omeyer]] during a seven-metre throw]]
==Equipment== To avoid confusion, a handball goalkeeper has to wear a jersey that is different in colour to all the other jerseys of the players on the field, including the other team's goalkeeper. If such a jersey is not available the goalkeeper has to wear a [[:de:Leibchen|bib]] that guarantees sufficient distinction between players involved. Most goalkeepers also wear special long trousers and male goalkeepers always wear a [[jockstrap]] (a undergarment serving protection purposes). Rule 4:9<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihf.info/en-us/thegame/statutesandregulations.aspx|title=Statutes and Regulations|last=Portal|first=IHF|website=www.ihf.info|accessdate=2016-12-14}}</ref> (concerning equipment during the game) states that it is mandatory for the players to wear sports shoes during the games. Unlike in football, handball goalkeepers do not equip with gloves although this is not prohibited by the rules.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} Gloves are in fact rejected because they are regarded as a sign of weakness amongst fellow goalkeepers and also worsen the throwing ability of the goalkeeper.{{By whom|section=Discussion about whom|date=March 2018}} Additional [[Protective gear in sports|protective gear]] like face masks and helmets had been discused in the early days of the game, but are nowadays prohibited, as are any items that could endanger the opposing players including piercings, necklaces, earrings and glasses. [[File:Goalkeeper handball penalty shot.jpg|thumb|A woman goalkeeper during a seven-metre throw]]
==Rules for the goalkeeper== All rules can be found on the IHF website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihf.info/files/Uploads/NewsAttachments/0_New-Rules%20of%20the%20Game_GB.pdf |format=PDF |title=IX. Rules of the Game |website=Ihf.info |accessdate=2016-12-22}}</ref>
A team has to appoint one player on the field as the goalie. However, a goalie can transition to a field player at any time during a game. In order to do this he needs to be substituted and change his goalie jersey to a field player's jersey. A field player can assume the goalkeeper's position in the same manner. Rule 5<ref name="regel5">{{cite web|url=http://www.handballregeln.de/show.php?datei=r5.inc|publisher=handballregeln.de|title=Regel 5 (www.handballregeln.de)|accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> <nowiki>''</nowiki>The Goalkeeper<nowiki>''</nowiki> deals with all the rules pertaining to the goalie and a set of special rules about the goal area. Inside this area the goalkeeper is allowed to touch the ball with every part of his body in order to parry the ball. Additionally, several rules do not apply to the goalie inside the goal area. These rules are: the 3-second-rule (7:2), the 3-step-rule (7:3), the rule for bouncing the ball (7:4) and the multiple-touching-of-the-ball-rule (7:7). However, if the goalie purposefully delays playing the ball a referee can call passive gameplay.
The goalie is allowed to step out of the goal area and onto the playing field when not in possession of the ball at all times. While outside the goal area all rules pertaining to field players apply to him as well. Furthermore, he is allowed to step out of the goal area with the ball while he is still trying to get it under control (5:4). The goalkeeper is not allowed to leave the goal area with the ball under control if the referee has whistled for the execution of a goalkeeper-throw (5:6). This throw has to be executed within the goal area. Rule 5:7+8 stipulate that while standing inside the goal area the goalkeeper is not allowed to touch a rolling or stationary ball outside the goal area. Moreover, he is not allowed to re-enter the goal area from the playing field with the ball (5:9). The goalie must not touch the ball with his foot or the leg below the knee if the ball is moving out towards the playing area (5:10). During a 7-metre throw from the opposing team the goalkeeper is not allowed to cross the goalkeeper's restraining line (4-metre-line) before the ball has left the hand of the opposing player executing the throw (5.11).
If the ball crosses the outer goal line outside the goalposts and the goalkeeper was the last player to touch the ball, the keeper gets the ball to execute a goalkeeper-throw inside the goal area. However, if the ball crosses the sideline the opposing team gets the ball for a throw-in. [[File:Johannes Bitter 04.jpg|thumb|[[Johannes Bitter]]]] Sometimes the goalkeeper will be used as a seventh field player or substituted by a regular field player. This normally happens during the last minutes of play if the score is a tie or the attacking team is down by just a few points. The extra player is added to increase the team's chances for a win or a tie.
== Duties and requirements of a handball goalkeeper == The goalkeeper's primary task is to prevent the other team from scoring a goal, which is achieved when the ball fully passes the goal line. The game has become much more fast-paced over the years which demands that the goalkeeper has to bring the ball back into play very fast, leading to [[fast break]]s or turnovers which provide very good scoring chances. Strategies like the second wave or the so-called ''schnelle Mitte,'' are fast-action plays intended to catch the opposing team off guard. After having conceded a goal the keeper passes the ball immediately to the centre of the court for a throw-off. In some situation the goalkeeper even scores a goal himself by taking advantage of the fact that the other team's goalie is too far away from his own goal and throwing the ball across the whole field into the empty goal. The German goalkeeper Johannes Bitter managed to score two goals in that manner over the course of his 112 international games.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100330181714/http://www.dhb.de/index.php?id=bitter ''Johannes Bitter.''] ([[Web archiving|Memento]] vom 30. März 2010 im ''Internet Archive'') abgerufen am 27. November 2009.</ref>
Height is an important criterion for goalkeepers who want to play on a professional level. The rule of thumb in this regard is "the bigger the better". Dieter Bartke, a former goalkeeper of the German national league, was {{convert|2.16|m|abbr=on}} tall. Disadvantages in height are effectively compensated by other factors, like jumping power and flexibility of the body. Prominent examples are Wieland Schmidt ({{convert|1.85|m|abbr=on|disp=sqbr}} tall) and Henning Fritz ({{convert|1.88|m|abbr=on|disp=sqbr}}). Skills such as quick reflexes, quick comprehension and a distinct anticipation ability are considered more important than height. Modern handball training is focused on improving a goalkeeper's anticipation of typical in-game situations by implementing the so-called standard situation, a concept that simulates a set of the most common scenarios that can happen in a game. Sports scientists coined the phrase ''Aktionsmuster,'' action patterns, which goalkeepers try to embed in their subconsciousness. [[File:Daouda Karaboue 01.jpg|thumb|[[Daouda Karaboué]]]]
==Common goalkeeper injuries== Problems in the [[elbow]] area are most common among handball goalies. In 1992 a study conducted in Norway reported that 329 out of 729 (45%) handball goalkeepers suffered from pain in the elbow joint area. In contrast to these numbers only 166 out of 4120 (4%) field players complained about similar problems. In a follow-up survey out of these 729 goalkeepers 41% had acute problems and 34% reported past problems in the area. The health problem caused recurring pain and often the goalkeepers had to stop playing for several games due to injury. The apparent cause for these injuries is a repeated overextension of the elbow joint while trying to parry a ball. The authors of the study call the syndrome the ''handball goalie's elbow.''<ref>S. Tyrdal, R. Bahr: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=8960652&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''High prevalence of elbow problems among goalkeepers in European team handball – 'handball goalie's elbow'.''] In: ''Scand J Med Sci Sports.'' 6/1996, S. 297–302. {{PMID|8960652}}</ref><ref>M. A. Ferrara u. a.: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=10589171&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''Modifications of the elbow induced by the practice of handball on radiography, US and MRI.''] In: ''JBR-BTR.'' 82/1999, S. 222–227. {{PMID|10589171}}</ref><ref>S. Tyrdal, A. M. Finnanger: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=10220843&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''Osseous manifestations of 'handball goalie's elbow'.''] In: ''Scand J Med Sci Sports.'' 9/1999, S. 92–97. {{PMID|10220843}}</ref><ref>S. Tyrdal, O. J. Pettersen: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=9502308&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''The effect of strength training on 'handball goalie's elbow'--a prospective uncontrolled clinical trial.''] In: ''Scand J Med Sci Sports.'' 8/1998, S. 33–41. {{PMID|9502308}}</ref> This hyperextension trauma of the elbow can also frequently occur during joint-lock techniques in [[judo]].
The cause for this type of pain is most probably damage to the [[ulnar nerve]].<ref>I. R. Rise u. a.: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=11476431&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''Is the ulnar nerve damaged in 'handball goalie's elbow'?''] In: ''Scand J Med Sci Sports.'' 11/2001, S. 247–250. {{PMID|11476431}}</ref> A definite diagnosis is the main focus of current studies in order to develop suffiecient prevention and treatment methods.<ref>U. Akgun u. a.: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&Cmd=ShowDetailView&TermToSearch=17899010&ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVAbstractPlus ''Direction of the load on the elbow of the ball blocking handball goalie.''] In: ''Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc.'' 26. September 2007, {{PMID|17899010}}</ref>
== Further remarks == [[File:Dejan Peric 04.jpg|thumb|[[Dejan Perić]]]] If a goalkeeper receives a two-minute suspension he has to leave the field and is replaced by another goalkeeper, usually forcing his team to continue playing with one player less on the field. It has been under discussion for several years whether goalkeepers should be forbidden to step outside the goal area during fast breaks, a rule which has caused a lot of accidents between the goalie and field players.<ref>J. Bierschwale: [https://www.welt.de/print-welt/article490681/Unfall-schockt-Handball-Liga-Jakobsen-fordert-Konsequenzen.html ''Unfall schockt Handball-Liga: Jakobsen fordert Konsequenzen.''] In: ''Die Welt.'' 3. Dezember 2001.</ref>
If both teams have similar performance during a game, the goalkeeper's individual performance can have a huge impact on the outcome of the game. A ratio of 25 percent saves and more is regarded a very good performance with 50 percent saves very rarely being achieved over a time period of thirty minutes.
The [[jumping jack]] is a typical goalkeeper's defensive movement while trying to save the ball.
When a player's throw hits the goalkeeper's head, for example, from a seven-meter throw, the player will be disqualified (rule 8:5).<ref name="regel8">{{cite web|url=http://www.handballregeln.de/show.php?datei=r8.inc|publisher=handballregeln.de|title=Regel 8 (www.handballregeln.de)|accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> [[File:Henning Fritz 02.jpg|thumb|[[Henning Fritz]]]] [[File:Peter Gentzel 01.jpg|thumb|[[Peter Gentzel]]]] [[File:M Mueller T Omeyer 02.jpg|thumb|[[Thierry Omeyer]] performing the [[jumping jack]]]]
== Notable goalkeepers == {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2018}}<!--Since these have their own articles this could stand without references if their achievements are removed from the list. It's the achievements and statistics that require references.--> * [[Mattias Andersson (handballer)|Mattias Andersson]] (several times German champion, European champion with Sweden in 2000, multiple time [[EHF Champions League]] winner) * [[Johannes Bitter]] ([[EHF Cup]] winner, World champion in 2007, German champion in 2011) * [[Henning Fritz]] (World champion in 2007, [[IHF World Player of the Year]] in 2004) * [[Martin Galia]] (best goalkeeper during the 2005–06 season in the German [[Handball-Bundesliga|HBL]] with 508 saves, EHF finalist in 2006) * [[Peter Gentzel]] (213 international matches for Sweden, three times European champion, one time World champion) * [[:de:Stefan Hecker|Stefan Hecker]] (several times German champion and Cup winner, German Player of the Year 1990) * [[Silvio Heinevetter]] (2004 European junior champion, EHF Cup winner in 2007) * [[Kasper Hvidt]] (European champion in 2008, bronze medal winner of the European championship 2002, 2004, 2006 and at the World championship 2007) * [[Niklas Landin Jacobsen]] (European champion in 2012) * [[Andrey Lavrov|Andrei Lawrow]] (three times Olympic champion, World champion and European champion) * [[Cecilie Leganger]] (World champion in 1999, World female player of the Year in 2001) * [[Thierry Omeyer]] (several times French and German champion, World champion in 2001,2009 and 2011, European champion in 2006 and 2010, Olympic champion in 2008, World Player of the Year in 2008) * [[Christian Ramota]] (European champion in 2004) * [[Siegfried Roch|Sigi Roch]] (winner of the Olympic silver medal in 1984, one-time European champion, two times German champion, three times German Cup winner) * [[Wieland Schmidt]] (Olympic champion in 1980 with the [[East Germany|GDR]] team) * [[Arpad Šterbik]] (World Player of the Year in 2005, several times Spanish and Hungarian champion) * [[Sławomir Szmal]] (Goalkeeper of the Polish international team, currently goalkeeper of the handball club KS Vive Targi Kielce S.A.) * [[Andreas Thiel]] (Nicknamed ''the magician'', seven times German Player of the Year, five times German champion) * [[Andreas Wolff]] (European champion with Germany in 2016)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Literature== * A. Thiel u. a.: ''Halten wie wir.'' Philippka-Verlag, 1999, {{ISBN|3-89417-079-4}}. * D. Späte u. a.: ''Handball Handbuch.'' Philippka Verlag, 1997, {{ISBN|3-89417-063-8}}. * J. Schorer: [http://d-nb.info/983925763/34 ''Höchstleistung im Handballtor.''] [[Dissertation]]. Ruprecht-Karls-Universität, Heidelberg 2006.
==External links== * Tom de Meller: [http://www.freitag.de/autoren/der-freitag/triumph-und-schmerzschreie ''Triumph- und schmerzschreie.''] In: ''Freitag.'' 9. Februar 2001. * [http://www.torhueter.ch/ Torhueter.ch] * [http://www.jhse.ua.es/article/view/2013-v8-n3-proc-action-sequence-analysis-in-team-handball action patterns] {{Goalkeeper}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Huntington Center | image = [[Image:LucasCountyArena.jpg|250px]] | location = 500 Jefferson Avenue
[[Toledo, Ohio]] 43604 | broke_ground = October 1, 2007 | built = | opened = October 3, 2009{{cite news |title=Lucas County Arena Sparkles as Thousands Get Sneak Peek|first=Ryan E.|last=Smith|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/local/2009/10/04/Lucas-County-Arena-sparkles-as-thousands-get-sneak-peek.html|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=October 4, 2009|accessdate=February 12, 2013}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Lucas County, Ohio|Lucas County]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | surface = Ice | construction_cost = $105 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|105000000|2009}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[HNTB]]
The Collaborative Inc. | project_manager = Project Management Consultants LLC[http://www.aboutpmc.com/projects/profile.php?ID=35 Project Management Consultants: Lucas County Arena] | structural engineer = Poggemeyer Design Group{{cite web |title=Huntington Center Superstructure & Sustainable Site Design|url=http://www.poggemeyer.com/services/services_structural4.htm|publisher=Poggemeyer Design Group|accessdate=October 22, 2011}} | services engineer = M-E Engineers, Inc.[http://www.reedconstructiondata.com/building-types/arenas/ohio/projects/1000748052/ Lucas County Multi Purpose Arena Bp 2] | general_contractor = [[Turner Construction|Lathrop]]/R. Gant LLC{{cite news |title=Commissioners Seek Arena Work for Minority Firms|first=Joe|last=Vardon|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/local/2007/05/22/Commissioners-seek-arena-work-for-minority-firms.html|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=May 22, 2007|accessdate=February 12, 2013}} | former_names = Lucas County Arena (2009–2010) | tenants = [[Toledo Walleye]] ([[ECHL]]) (2009–present)
[[Toledo Crush]] ([[Legends Football League|LFL]]) (2014) | seating_capacity = Concerts: 4,784 (half-house)
5,903 (3/4 house)
7,286 (End-stage)
9,341 (center-stage)
Basketball: 8,000
Ice Hockey: 7,389 (8,200 with standing room) }} The '''Huntington Center''' is an 8,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]]{{cite news |title=Toledo Project in the Running for First New "Green" Arena|first=Don|last=Muret|url=http://m.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2008/06/20080623/Facilities/Toledo-Project-In-The-Running-For-First-New-Green-Arena.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Journal|date=June 23, 2008|accessdate=July 13, 2008}} in [[Downtown Toledo|downtown]] [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]], [[Ohio]]. It was completed in 2009{{cite news |title=Groundbreaking Set for Downtown Toledo Arena|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=September 28, 2007|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070928/NEWS16/70928005| accessdate=March 27, 2008}} and cost [[United States dollar|$]]105 million to build.{{cite news |title=Building Costs Vary for Arena Downtown Toledo|first=Joe|last=Vardon|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071010/NEWS16/710100406|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=October 10, 2007|accessdate=March 27, 2008}} It replaced the [[Toledo Sports Arena]], which has since been demolished.{{cite news |title=Demolition Work for Arena Likely to Begin in Summer|first=Erica|last=Blake|url=http://toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070125/NEWS16/701250338|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=January 15, 2007|accessdate=March 27, 2008}} It serves as the home of the [[Toledo Walleye]] [[ECHL]] [[ice hockey]] team,{{cite web |title=Toledo Arena Sports, Inc. Acquire ECHL Hockey Team|first=Jason|last=Griffin|date=April 16, 2007|url=http://www.mudhens.com/view_press.asp?id=269|publisher=Toledo Arena Sports, Inc.|accessdate=March 27, 2008}} and was the home of the [[Toledo Crush]] of the [[Legends Football League]] for the 2014 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.clevelandleader.com/node/21900 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707024356/http://www.clevelandleader.com/node/21900 |archivedate=2014-07-07 |df= }} ==History== After a successful partnership on the Mud Hens Stadium ([[Fifth Third Field (Toledo)|Fifth Third Field]]), the Lucas County Commissioners teamed with HNTB Architecture Inc., a national sports architecture firm located in [[Kansas City, MO|Kansas City]]; The Collaborative Inc., of Toledo; and Poggemeyer Design Group, of Toledo, for a new arena.{{cite web |title=Lucas County Arena Project|url=http://www.lucascountyarena.com|publisher=Lucas County|accessdate=January 1, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080125182233/http://www.lucascountyarena.com/|archivedate=January 25, 2008|deadurl=yes}} The arena was designed as the first new [[Leadership in Energy and Environment Design|LEED]] sports arena in the United States. The arena's signature green design element is a {{convert|900|sqft|m2|adj=on}} "green wall" outside of the building, to feature the use of plant life on the exterior of the building to help cool the arena by shading the glass-enclosed main entrance of the arena. The arena's location near mass transit systems, use of a light-colored roof membrane to reflect heat and sunlight, and underground cisterns collecting rain water to re-use for landscaping purposes around the arena, are also emphasized to earn LEED points for the project. The Huntington Center opened in 2009 ==Notable events== The arena is part of a complex that includes [[SeaGate Convention Centre]] and [[Fifth Third Field (Toledo)|Fifth Third Field]]. The first person to perform at this venue was [[Jeff Dunham]]. Other performances that have happened at the Huntington Center include: [[Daughtry (band)|Daughtry]], [[Tool (band)|Tool]], [[Rascal Flatts]], [[Carrie Underwood]], [[Elton John]], [[Brad Paisley]], [[Stevie Nicks]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Jason Aldean]], [[Hunter Hayes]], and [[Bob Seger]]. It is also the Toledo-area stop for [[World Wrestling Entertainment]]. [[File:LucasCountyArena.PNG|thumb|left|alt=logo for Lucas County Arena (former name)|The Huntington Center was formerly known as the Lucas County Arena]] [[Huntington Bancshares|Huntington Bancshares Incorporated]] bought the naming rights to Lucas County Arena in April 2010 and renamed it as the Huntington Center. The six-year, $2.1 million naming rights and sponsorship agreement includes three renewal options of six years each, and could mean total Huntington payments of $11 million. The proceeds are to be applied to paying down the arena's $90 million debt.{{cite news |title=Downtown Toledo Arena Gets a New Name; Bank Agrees to Purchase Rights for $2.1 Million|first=Larry P.|last=Vellequette|url=http://toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100416/BUSINESS03/4160356|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=April 16, 2010|accessdate=April 16, 2010}} The Huntington Center will host the [[ECHL All-Star Game|2019 CCM/ECHL All Star Classic]] on January 21, 2019.{{cite web |url=http://www.echl.com/toledo-walleye-host-2019-ccm-echl-star-classic|title= Walleye to host 2019 CCM/ECHL All-Star Classic |accessdate= 2017-04-10 | date = 2017-04-08}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.huntingtoncentertoledo.com/ Huntington Center official site] *[http://wtol.images.worldnow.com/images/incoming/arenaplans.pdf Lucas County Arena Renderings] {{coord|41.6498596|-83.5372281|display=t|type:landmark|format=dms}} {{Toledo Walleye}} {{ECHL Arenas}} {{LFL Venues}} {{Toledo}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Toledo, Ohio]] [[Category:Toledo Walleye]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Toledo, Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Ohio]]

The '''Kazakhstan Rugby Union''' is the governing body for [[rugby union]] in [[Kazakhstan]]. It is a member of the [[International Rugby Board]].
The Union organises the [[Kazakhstan national rugby union team]], known as the ''Nomads''.
==See also== * [[Rugby union in Kazakhstan]]
==External links== * [http://www.kaz-rugby.kz/ Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310160757/http://impressions-ba.com/features.php?id_feature=10392 Tries and Tribulations] * [http://www.heavensgame.com/luke-ocallaghan/ Luke O'Callaghan's Blog about Kazakhstan Rugby]
{{IRB Unions}} {{Women's Rugby World Cup Unions}}
[[Category:Rugby union in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Rugby union governing bodies in Europe]]
{{Kazakhstan-sport-stub}} {{Rugbyunion-stub}}

{{Use British English|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox cricket club | name = London New Zealand Cricket Club ("LNZCC") | image = LNZCC logo.png | oneday_name = | second_team = | coach = | bowlingcoach = | fielding_coach = | captain = | od_captain = | overseas = | colors = Red, Pacific Blue and Silver | founded = December 1951 | ground = Wandering side formerly Aorangi Park (Wimbledon) until 1981 | capacity = | owner = | Chairman = | manager = | adviser = | first_fc = | first_fc_year = | first_fc_venue = | title1 = | title1wins = | title2 = | title2wins = | title3 = | title3wins = | title4 = | title4wins = | website = {{URL|http://www.lnzcc.org}} }} The '''London New Zealand Cricket Club''' is a [[cricket]] club in [[London]], [[England]], founded in December 1951 at [[High Commission of New Zealand, London|New Zealand's High Commission to the United Kingdom]] and plays teams in the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Europe]].
Various players of the [[New Zealand national cricket team]] (and other international cricket teams), the [[New Zealand national rugby union team|All Blacks]], and [[first-class cricket|first-class]] players have appeared for the club over the years, although players of all abilities are welcome provided they are from [[New Zealand]] or have a deep connection thereto.
LNZCC raises its own teams and plays non-competition games at the grounds of the opposition. Many of the teams are competitive club teams or established friendly teams and many of the grounds are notable for their location and quality, for example, the early season fixture against [http://www.thewimbledonclub.co.uk/cricket Wimbledon] who play in the [[Surrey Championship]] and who play at the [[Wimbledon Cricket Club Ground]], located opposite the [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]; the match vs the [[Honourable Artillery Company]] who play at the [[Artillery Ground]] in [[Finsbury]] in the [[City of London]]; against [[The Hurlingham Club]], an exclusive [[sports club|sports]] and [[social club|social]] club located in [[Fulham]], London, England. Other notable fixtures are played at Ripley in Surrey, vs [[Goodwood Cricket Club|Goodwood]] on The Duke of Richmond and Gordon's estate overlooking Goodwood House near Chichester and against Hagley CC at [[Hagley Hall]], the seat of the Lyttelton family and home of current Lord Chris and Lady Tessa Cobham. The club has also played against touring New Zealand cricket team sides and the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.lnzcc.org/notable-games.html|title=Notable games|work=London New Zealand Cricket Club}}</ref>
== History and role == {{copypaste | url=http://www.lnzcc.org/history.html |date=September 2015}}<!-- 81.144.146.180 21 February 2017 claimed that this was used with permission of LNZCC, but you need to send this form to Wikipedia to confirm such permission - [[Wikipedia:Declaration of consent for all enquiries]] -->
The genesis of LNZCC was New Zealander Trevor Campbell shortly after [[World War II]], in his role as the ‘Public Relations Officer’ of the NZ High Commission. Campbell posited that the UK was very grateful to New Zealand for its assistance of [[Great Britain]] in World War II and such signs of gratitude could be extended through cricket, a game widely popular in both countries, and that games could be played against teams who would no doubt feature returned servicemen who fought with New Zealanders during World War II.
Campbell was based at the New Zealand High Commission in the former ‘Dominion of New Zealand’ building, [http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/34265/new-zealand-house-london-around-the-1920s 415] [[Strand, London|The Strand]], London and sought the help of [[Errol Holmes]] former [[England]] test cricketer, MCC captain to New Zealand in 1935/36 and then-current MCC committee member, in establishing a club. With the added support of NZ High Commissioner Sir [[Frederick Doidge]] and the MCC, Campbell invited more than 200 well-known [[New Zealanders]] living in the UK to meet.
LNZCC was formed at the New Zealand High Commission in December 1951 on one of the worst nights of the infamous London Pea Souper [[Great Smog|fogs]] - freezing smogs laden with toxic and deadly industrial pollutants which lasted for days on end. It was decided that the aim of LNZCC (which continues to this day, as well as meeting at the New Zealand High Commission building for a mid-season function) was to ''‘provide the opportunity for its members to play and enjoy cricket in the home of the game and to meet socially’''.
More than 70 people attended the meeting that formed LNZCC including many illustrious sporting and military names. In attendance – Sir Arthur Simms; Sir Arthur Donnelly; Harold Gilligan (Captain of the England team that played New Zealand’s first ever test;) LEL Donne; Walter Hadlee; Roger Blunt; Alan Mitchell amongst others. At the meeting, [[Roger Blunt]], a former New Zealand cricket team captain, was made the first Club Captain and Errol Holmes the first President, Campbell Honorary Secretary and invitations to stand as Vice-President were sent to then New Zealand Prime Minister Sir Sidney Holland and to High Commissioner Sir Frederick Doidge. The first two men elected VP were Lord Newall (Cyril Newall, ex Governor-General of NZ and Marshall of the Royal Air Force during WW2) and Lord Freyberg VC (as General Bernard Freyberg, Commander of the NZ Expeditionary Force in WW2; earlier in his career he was awarded the Victoria Cross in the Battle of the Somme in 1916; later he was Governor- General of NZ.)
Amongst the active members of LNZCC were New Zealand test cricketers Tom Pritchard, Don Taylor, Roger Blunt, Bill Merritt and John Reid; Jim Laker, Ray Hitchcock (327 first-class games and 12,500 runs) and former All Black captain Ron Elvidge.
A fixture list was soon created and the following year LNZCC was listed in the MCC's 'Register of Clubs' at [[Lord's Cricket Ground]].<ref name="lnzcc.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.lnzcc.org/inaugural-season.html|title=Inaugural season|work=London New Zealand Cricket Club}}</ref>
The Club Captain role has long since ceased but the President role continues with a change to 'Chairman' and together with a committee, LNZCC continues to attract cricket-playing New Zealanders and a small number of friends from the Commonwealth.
LNZCC celebrated its [[Golden Jubilee]] in 2002, when Paddy Gaffikin, an LNZCC newcomer in the 1966 season when New Zealanders arrived in the United Kingdom on ocean liners rather than long-haul aeroplanes, authored a history of the club entitled 'Kiwis on the Common'.<ref name="Common 2002">{{cite book|last1=Gaffikin |first1=Paddy |title=Kiwis on the Common |date=2002 |publisher=Tasman Publications |isbn=0954262107}}</ref> The Golden Jubilee season, and [[Diamond Jubilee]] season in 2012, were both celebrated at [[The Oval]], home ground of the [[Surrey cricket team]] (who LNZCC has also played<ref name="auto"/>).
LNZCC continues to this day through the help of volunteers who provide a cricketing base and network for UK-based New Zealanders, be they young 'backpackers' on their 'OE', sportsmen playing in the UK, or established business people. Current and past membership of LNZCC is wide and illustrious. LNZCC also has branches in [[Auckland]], [[Wellington]] and [[Christchurch]], New Zealand and games are played in LNZCC colours by members in New Zealand.
== Interesting facts == One of the most striking elements of LNZCC is the visually-appealing striped blazers worn by members to games and social events. The blazers are made up of vertical stripes in the colours of the club - representing [[The City of London]] (red), the [[Silver Fern]] which is a sporting symbol of [[New Zealand]] (silver) and the blue symbolises the waters of the Pacific Ocean (Pacific blue). Blazing bright in colour and mass, they are often captured by the media at test matches, Lord's Cricket Ground, The Oval and have been spotted at All Black test matches amongst others. They've featured in news articles too.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10884619|title=Cricket: Expat club plays crucial role for all sorts of Kiwis|work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref>
[http://www.ripleycc.com Ripley] Cricket Club is the only fixture to have been played uninterrupted since the first season in 1952.
Since 2008 all LNZCC players are capped with ‘Nottman Caps’ once they have played five games. The Nottman Cap is named after Harold Nottman who was one of LNZCC's longest-serving playing members (from the 1950s to the 1990s no less) and a notable administrator in the club's history. One of his finest days on the cricket field for LNZCC was against [[Ripley Cricket Club]] when he took nine wickets in a match.
Overseas tours have included Porto in Portugal, matches vs teams in Denmark in the 1960s and a special match vs the Monte Carlo Cricket Club in Bouyon in the Alpes-Maritime near Nice. Since 2013, LNZCC has toured the Mediterranean for matches in [[Ibiza]], [[Spain]] against the island's [http://ibizacricketclub.com cricket] team.
Naturally, members of the club are supporters of the New Zealand cricket team and have often made the news when traveling around the world for that purpose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11424792|title=Wish comes true for cricket crazy couple|work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref>
==Notable players==
List principally sourced from 'Kiwis on the Common'<ref name="Common 2002"/>
New Zealand national cricket team
* [[Martin Donnelly (cricketer)|Martin Donnelly]] * [[Don Taylor (cricketer)|Don Taylor]] * [[Ray Hitchcock]] * [[Roger Blunt]] * [[Bill Merritt (cricketer)|Bill Merritt]] * [[John Guy (New Zealand cricketer)|John Guy]] * [[Bill Merritt (cricketer)|Bill Merritt]] * [[Billy Griffith]] * [[John Richard Reid|John Reid]] * [[Dayle Hadlee]] * [[Eric Gillott]] * [[Sir Richard Hadlee]] * [[Martin Crowe]] * [[Bert Sutcliffe]] * [[Aaron Gale]] * [[Hamish Marshall]] * [[Jack Kerr (cricketer)|Jack Kerr]] * [[Bob Cunis]] * [[Ian Cromb]] * [[Tony MacGibbon]] * [[Dave Crowe]] * [[Andre Adams]] * [[Graeme Thomson (cricketer)|Graeme Thomson]]
(A number of first-class and List A players who have not played internationally have also played for the club, e.g. [[Scott Baldwin]], [[Luke Vivian]], and various Oxford and Cambridge Blues players)
All Blacks
* [[Zinzan Brooke]] * [[Ron Elvidge]] * [[Sam Harding (rugby union)|Sam Harding]] * [[Ian Botting]] * [[Tony Davies]] * [[Scott Cartwright]]

{{Infobox rugby team | teamname = Ragbi klub Nikšić | image = | imagesize = | nickname = ''Lavovi'' (Lions) | founded = 2013 | location = [[Nikšić]], [[Montenegro]] | ground = Glava Zete venue | capacity = 100(seated) | president = Dimitrije Cvorovic | coach = Miodrag Jovic | league = Montenegrin national division | season = 2013/14 | position = | pattern_la1 =| pattern_b1 =| pattern_ra1 =| leftarm1 = FF0| body1 = FF0| rightarm1 = FF0| shorts1 = 000| socks1 = 000 }} '''Ragbi klub Nikšić''' is a Montenegrin [[Rugby union|rugby]] club based in Nikšić. It is the third youngest club in Montenegro. The first session was held on "Trebjesa" field on September 15, 2013. Since then, the club operates regularly on a semi-pro level. The biggest achievement of this young club is the third place that was won at international memorial tournament "Luka Marin" Novi Sad. Nowadays, the club is competing in Montenegrin national league which consists of 5 clubs (Arsenal, Buducnost, Niksic, Lovcen and Mornar). revision.text:
{{Infobox_Golf_Facility |golf_facility_name = Rock Creek Park Golf Course |image = |location = [[Washington, D.C.]] |establishment = 1909 |type = Public |caption = |operator = Golf Course Specialists, Inc. |tournaments = |website = http://www.golfdc.com |course1 = Rock Creek Park Golf Course |designer1 = |par1 = 65
|length1 = {{convert|4886|yd}} |rating1 = |record1 = }} '''Rock Creek Park Golf Course''' (also known as '''Rock Creek Golf Course''') is a [[golf course]] located in [[Washington, D.C.]], in the [[United States]]. The entire course lies within [[Rock Creek Park]], a [[national park]] owned and maintained by the [[National Park Service]] division of the [[United States Department of the Interior]].
The course is located at the intersection of 16th Street NW and Rittenhouse Street NW. The course is bordered by Military Road NW in the south, [[Rock Creek (Potomac River)|Rock Creek]] and Beach Drive NW on the west, Sherrill Drive NW on the north, and 16th Street NW in the east. [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]] is immediately to the northwest.
Rock Creek Park Golf Course is one of three golf courses in Washington, D.C., all of which are owned by the National Park Service. The other two are [[East Potomac Park Golf Course]] and [[Langston Golf Course]].
==Course description== Rock Creek Golf Course is known as a challenging course.<ref name="Thompson" /> The front nine holes are short par 4s and long par 3s, although the broad fairways have some elevation differences.<ref name="Thompson" /><ref name="Karlin">Karlin and St. Louis, ''Washington, D.C.,'' 2010, p. 199.</ref> The fairways of the back nine are tight, with dense deciduous woods on either side. Elevation changes on the back nine are even more significant, and many of the greens are quite small.<ref name="Thompson" /><ref>Sehlinger, Surkiewicz, and Zibart, ''The Unofficial Guide to Washington, D.C.,'' 1994, p. 188.</ref><ref name="Karlin" /> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described the course one way in 1999:<ref>"Rock Creek's Back Nine: A Steep Challenge," ''Washington Post,'' June 20, 1999.</ref> :Want a unique, virtually free, profoundly humbling golf experience? Try the back nine at Rock Creek Golf Club. Rock Creek is one of two remaining public golf courses in the city, not as well known as East Potomac Park perhaps, but unforgettable once you've scrambled up the precipitous slopes in the shadow of towering trees, dodged deer and leaped deep ravines in a single bound. And that's in the fairway. The front nine is so wide open it's boring. The backside seems to have been designed by a mountain goat. Not a flat lie in the place, but one spectacular vista after another, not to mention almost comically devious golfing challenges.
Services at the course include a large putting green, snack bar, and golf school.<ref name="Thompson">Thompson, ''National Geographic Traveler: Washington, D.C.,'' 2008, p. 263.</ref> Players have criticized the maintenance of the course in the past. However, at least one reviewer says that Rock Creek's "weedy fairways, shaggy greens, <nowiki>[and]</nowiki> no frills" clubhouse is "honest" municipal golf.<ref>Cullen, ''Why Golf?: The Mystery of the Game Revisited,'' 2002, p. 34.</ref>
==History== Rock Creek Park was established on September 27, 1890. In January 1905, citizens in the [[Brightwood, Washington, D.C.|Brightwood]] neighborhood proposed building a golf course in Rock Creek Park.<ref>"Col. Biddle Wins Praise," ''Washington Post,'' January 19, 1905.</ref> The [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]], which controlled the city and the parks within it at the time, approved the plan in November 1906 (although there was opposition, which believed money should be spent on [[public health]] project first).<ref>"Public Golf Links Soon," ''Washington Post,'' November 3, 1906; "Provide Free Sports," ''Washington Post,'' November 6, 1906; "Oppose New Golf Course," ''Washington Post,'' December 23, 1906.</ref> Construction began in 1907, and a nine-hole course opened on July 1, 1909.<ref>"Golf Course to Be Ideal," ''Washington Post,'' September 1, 1907; "Only A Half Course," ''Washington Post,'' May 8, 1909.</ref> The course's first clubhouse was a former farm house owned by Horatio Plant<ref>{{cite news|title=Scribe Golfers Have High Aspirations|work=The Evening Star|date=April 22, 1923|page=70|accessdate=February 26, 2018|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1923-04-22/ed-1/seq-70/}}</ref>, and its first concessionaires were N.B. Frost and H.D. Miller.<ref>West, "Rock Creek Links Concessions Let," ''Washington Post,'' March 8, 1923.</ref> After a year, the concession was turned over to Severine G. Leoffler, Sr.<ref name="Whittlesey">Whittlesey, "'New Deal' Is Planned For Golfers," ''Washington Post,'' December 31, 1938.</ref> His firm had first started managing Park Service courses in the city in 1921.<ref name="Whittlesey" /> Loeffler, who rose from extreme poverty to own a popular local restaurant and then became a noted concessionaire for the National Park Service,<ref>"Leoffler Bid For Links Is Low," ''Washington Post,'' December 22, 1935.</ref> administered Rock Creek Park Golf Course and other city golf courses for the next four decades.
Rock Creek Golf Course proved popular in its first few years. In July 1924, the Corps of Engineers agreed to expand the course to 18 holes.<ref>"Plan 18-Hole Golf Course at Rock Creek," ''Washington Post,'' July 22, 1924.</ref> However, construction needs were so extensive that the entire course was shuttered in December 1924.<ref>"Rock Creek Course to Close for Repairs," ''Washington Post,'' December 28, 1924.</ref> The course re-opened in 1926 with all 18 holes open for play.<ref name="LinksOpened">"Rock Creek's Links Are Opened," ''Washington Post,'' April 3, 1926.</ref> The first golfers to tee off on the new, complete course were four members of the [[United States Congress]], who hit the first ball at 5:53 AM.<ref name="LinksOpened" />
Twice in the 1930s the clubhouse suffered extensive fires. The first incident occurred in January 1933, when the clubhouse was damaged by a fire.<ref>"Fire Hits Clubhouse at Rock Creek Links," ''Washington Post,'' January 21, 1933.</ref> A larger fire burned the clubhouse to the ground in March 1937.<ref>"Fire Destroys Rock Creek's Golf House," ''Washington Post,'' March 18, 1937.</ref> Maintenance of the course was a major issue in the 1940s. Golfers complained about the course so vehemently that [[United States Senate Energy Subcommittee on Public Lands and Forests|U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Public Lands]] began an investigation and asked the Park Service to delay renewing the firm's contract.<ref name="ExpertFinds">Walsh, "Expert Finds Faulty Golf Courses Here," ''Washington Post,'' April 3, 1949.</ref> A consultant strongly criticized the Leoffler firm's stewardship of the course.<ref name="ExpertFinds" /> The firm built a new clubhouse on the course in 1965.<ref>Ham, Rock Creek Golf Regulars Miss Homey, Rustic Touch of Old Days," ''Washington Post,'' January 21, 1965.</ref> But in 1968, Leoffler told the Park Service to close the course, as it was making no money.<ref name="Hodge" />
The National Park Service threatened to close Rock Creek Golf Course in 1981. The number of rounds played at Rock Creek rose from 9,500 in 1979 to 41,500 in 1980.<ref name="Hodge">Hodge, "1 of 3 Public Links in D.C. Closed," ''Washington Post,'' December 20, 1981.</ref> But a Park Service report concluded that the course had been allowed to seriously deteriorate since 1965, despite about $100,000 in course repairs in the past three years.<ref name="Hodge" /> The Leoffler company declined to renew its concessions contract in 1981, and the National Park Service said it would close the park without a new concessionaire.<ref name="Hodge" /> In mid-1982, however, a management team compose of local businessmen James R. Brock, Frank Coates, and William Torpey took over course management, leading to a significant increase in rounds played.<ref>Hodge, "Smaller Public Golf Course Sought," ''Washington Post,'' September 29, 1982; "E. Potomac Park Public Golf Course Gets New Manager," ''Washington Post,'' January 5, 1983.</ref> The new management team lasted only a year. In late 1982, the National Park Service awarded the concession to a new company, Golf Course Specialists, Inc.<ref>Eisen, "Golf Course to Reopen," ''Washington Post,'' April 8, 1983.</ref>
Rock Creek Golf Course came close to closing again in the 1990s. The National Park Service began soliciting public input on a new master plan for Rock Creek Park, the first such document in 80 years. The Park Service proposed four plans for comment, one of which would have closed the golf course.<ref>Wheeler, "Weighing Future of Rock Creek," ''Washington Post,'' July 27, 1996.</ref> After eight years of debate and study, a new master plan was adopted which retained Rock Creek Park Golf Course.<ref>Reel, "A Clash of Visions Over Rock Creek Park," ''Washington Post,'' June 24, 2004.</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}

New York: Simon & Schuster, 2002. *"Golf Course to Be Ideal." ''Washington Post.'' September 1, 1907. *"E. Potomac Park Public Golf Course Gets New Manager." ''Washington Post.'' January 5, 1983. *Eisen, Jack. "Golf Course to Reopen." ''Washington Post.'' April 8, 1983. *"Fire Destroys Rock Creek's Golf House." ''Washington Post.'' March 18, 1937. *"Fire Hits Clubhouse at Rock Creek Links." ''Washington Post.'' January 21, 1933. *Ham, Bus. "Rock Creek Golf Regulars Miss Homey, Rustic Touch of Old Days." ''Washington Post.'' January 21, 1965. *Hodge, Paul. "1 of 3 Public Links in D.C. Closed." ''Washington Post.'' December 20, 1981. *Hodge, Paul. "Smaller Public Golf Course Sought." ''Washington Post.'' September 29, 1982. *Karlin, Adam and St. Louis, Regis. ''Washington, D.C.'' Oakland, Calif.: Lonely Planet, 2010. *"Only A Half Course." ''Washington Post.'' May 8, 1909. *"Oppose New Golf Course." ''Washington Post.'' December 23, 1906. *"Plan 18-Hole Golf Course at Rock Creek." ''Washington Post.'' July 22, 1924. *"Provide Free Sports." ''Washington Post.'' November 6, 1906. *"Public Golf Links Soon." ''Washington Post.'' November 3, 1906. *Reel, Monte. "A Clash of Visions Over Rock Creek Park." ''Washington Post.'' June 20, 1999. *"Rock Creek's Links Are Opened." ''Washington Post.'' April 3, 1926. *Sehlinger, Bob; Surkiewicz, Joe; and Zibart, Eve. ''The Unofficial Guide to Washington, D.C.'' New York: Prentice Hall Travel, 1994. *Thompson, John. ''National Geographic Traveler: Washington, D.C.'' Washington, D.C.: National Geographic, 2008. *Walsh, Jack. "Expert Finds Faulty Golf Courses Here." ''Washington Post.'' April 3, 1949. *West, Henry Litchfield. "Rock Creek Links Concessions Let." ''Washington Post.'' March 8, 1923. *Wheeler, Linda. {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[Rugby union]] is a minor, but developing sport in [[Jordan]].
==Governing body== Jordanian rugby is administered by [[Jordan Rugby]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jordanrugby.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607093927/http://www.jordanrugby.com/ |archivedate=7 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which has been recognized by the [[Jordan Olympic Committee]] since 2007.
==History== Rugby was first introduced into Jordan by the [[British people|British]]. Since then, it has mainly been played by expatriates from the [[British Commonwealth]] and foreign workers.
Jordan maintains a close relationship with [[Arabian Gulf Rugby Football Union|AGRFU]], and their development team includes Ghaith Jalajel, a Jordanian.<ref>http://www.agrfu.com/page.php?id=86 retrieved 5 July 2009</ref>
There are regional teams at [[Petra University]] and elsewhere.
The [[Dubai Sevens]] has also helped stir up some interest in the sport in Arabic-speaking nations. Rugby union is quite popular in neighbouring [[Israel]], but the relations between the two nations means that there is little sporting contact between them. Jordanian rugby has its own [[rugby sevens|sevens]] and rugby 15s leagues that consists of Citadel Warriors RFC, Citadel Knights RFC, Nomads RFC, Amman Saracens and Aqaba Sharks.
===Lowest rugby match=== Jordan has hosted a rugby match at the lowest [[altitude]] ever recorded - at over 400 metres below [[sea level]] on the eastern shore of the [[Dead Sea]] on 29 October 1982.<ref name=RugDis>Cotton, p16</ref> This was between a team representing [[Aqaba]] and [[Safi, Jordan|Safi]] and another representing [[Amman]].<ref name=RugDis/> The temperature at the time, was in the 90s ([[fahrenheit]]).<ref name=RugDis/>
==National team== The [[Jordan national rugby union team]] is a third tier [[Rugby Union|rugby]] playing international side. Jordan played their first test match against {{nrut|Lebanon}} on 14 May 2010, in Dubai. They competed in and won the inaugural Asian 5 nations division 3 West competition in 2016.<ref>http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/qualifying/news/newsid=2037324.html#arabian+gulf+with+a5n+victory {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017132103/http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/qualifying/news/newsid%3D2037324.html |date=17 October 2014 }}</ref>
==Rugby Clubs in Jordan== There are three clubs in Amman: * Amman Citadel Rugby Club * Nomads Rugby Club * Amman Saracens Outside Amman: * Aqaba Sharks
==References== * Cotton, Fran (Ed.) (1984) ''The Book of Rugby Disasters & Bizarre Records''. Compiled by Chris Rhys. London. Century Publishing. {{ISBN|0-7126-0911-3}} * Richards, Huw ''A Game for Hooligans: The History of Rugby Union'' ([[Mainstream Publishing]], [[Edinburgh]], 2007, {{ISBN|978-1-84596-255-5}}) <references/>
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090607093927/http://www.jordanrugby.com/ Jordan Rugby Union] * [http://www.rugbyinasia.com/jordan/index.php Rugby in Asia, Jordan page] * [http://www.arfu.com/index.php Asian Rugby Football Union] * [http://wesclark.com/rrr/islamic_rugby.html "Islam and Rugby" on the ''Rugby Readers review''] * [http://www.citadelrfc.com Amman Citadel Rugby Club] * [https://www.facebook.com/NomadsRugbyClubAmman/] * [https://www.facebook.com/aqabasharks/]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Arsenal | image = | fullname = Sport Vereniging Arsenal | motto = | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1921|2|6}} | dissolved = | ground = [[Mr. Bronsplein]],
[[Paramaribo]], [[Suriname]] | capacity = | chrtitle = | chairman = | mgrtitle = | manager = | league = | season = | position = }} '''Sport Vereniging Arsenal''' ({{lang-en|Sports Union Arsenal}}) commonly abbreviated as '''SV Arsenal''', is a [[Suriname]]se [[association football|football]] club based in [[Nieuw Amsterdam, Suriname|Nieuw Amsterdam]] that played in the [[Hoofdklasse (Suriname)|Surinamese Hoofdklasse]], the highest level of football in Suriname.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_sur001192801_01/_sur001192801_01_0201.php |title=De Vraagbaak. Almanak voor Suriname 1928 |publisher=dbnl.org |accessdate=2015-12-12}} They play their home games on the [[Mr. Bronsplein]] in [[Paramaribo]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/surichamp.html |title=Surinam – List of Champions |publisher=RSSSF.com |accessdate=2015-12-12}} Named after the English football club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], the club was founded on 6 February 1921, and won the National championship twice, in the 1938–39 and the 1939–40 season.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/surifound.html |title=Surinam – List of Foundation Dates |publisher=RSSSF.com |accessdate=2015-12-12}} The club currently compete in the Domburg Sportbond (DSB) league, one of the amateur district leagues in Suriname.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dbsuriname.com/dbsuriname/index.php/arsenal-opent-competitie-met-overwinning/ |title=Arsenal opent competitie met overwinning |publisher=Dagblad Suriname|accessdate=2016-01-06}} ==Honours== *'''[[Surinamese League|Hoofdklasse]]''' ::'''Champions (2)''':1938–39, 1939–40 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/stut004eers01_01/stut004eers01_01.pdf De eerste Surinaamse sportencyclopedie (1893–1988)] by Ricky W. Stutgard {{Football in Suriname}} {{SVB Eerste Klasse}} {{Hoofdklasse (suriname)}} {{SVB Hoofdklasse champions}} [[Category:Football clubs in Suriname|Arsenal]] [[Category:Football clubs in Paramaribo|Arsenal]] [[Category:1921 establishments in Suriname]] {{Suriname-footyclub-stub}}

{{coord|42.561963|-87.824686|display=title}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2009}}
'''Simmons Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]]. It was the home field of the [[Kenosha Comets]] of the [[All-American Girls Professional Baseball League]] (AAGPBL).
==History==
Simmons Field opened in Kenosha in 1920 as a field for the [[Simmons Bedding Company|Simmons Bedding Company's]] baseball team. The stadium's original capacity was 7,000. The park allowed for growth of the company's Simmons Bedmakers team and provided a suitable venue city’s flourishing baseball rivalries.
The concrete grandstand was re-built in 1930. By that time, however, the city’s baseball teams had begun to decline despite a Midwest League championship for the Bedmakers in 1924.
In 1947, the Simmons Company sold the field and the city made it available the following year for use by the city's [[Women's baseball|women's professional baseball]] team, the [[Kenosha Comets]]. The Comets, of the [[All-American Girls Professional Baseball League]] (AAGPBL), had played in Kenosha at Lakefront Stadium since the league was founded in 1943. The team played at Simmons Field from 1948 until its final season in 1951. The AAGPBL folded three seasons later.
Throughout the ensuing decades, Simmons Field was used by little leagues, amateur leagues and for exhibition games. [[Warren Spahn]], [[Bob Feller]] and [[Satchel Paige]] [[Pitcher|pitched]] there. The Kenosha Pirates, a local semi-pro team, also played at Simmons Field during this era. But the stadium fell into disrepair without a major tenant.
Then in 1984, Kenosha native and former [[Minor League baseball|minor league]] pitcher [[Bob Lee (baseball)|Bob Lee]] transformed the old venue when he purchased the [[Minnesota Twins]] [[Single-A (baseball)|Single-A]] [[Midwest League]] affiliate and moved the team into Simmons Field. The move provided for approximately $350,000 worth of improvements to the field, including a new clubhouse, new in-ground dugouts, a new wood outfield fence, a new electronic scoreboard, concession facilities and aluminum bleachers along the third base line.
The Kenosha Twins played at Simmons Field for nine years, winning two Midwest League championships and producing more than a dozen major league players, including four players on the [[1991 Minnesota Twins season|Minnesota Twins 1991 World Championship team]]. That World Championship team included [[American League]] [[Major League Baseball Rookie of the Year Award|Rookie of the Year]] [[Chuck Knoblauch]] and long-time Kenosha resident and former [[University of Wisconsin–Parkside]] head baseball coach [[Jarvis Brown]], who played for the Kenosha Twins in 1987 and 1988. Current [[Carthage College]] head baseball coach Augie Schmidt also played at Simmons for the Twins in 1986, before retiring from professional baseball.
In July 1991, [[Chicago Cubs]] legend [[Rick Sutcliffe]] pitched nine innings in an injury rehab start for the [[Peoria Chiefs]] against the Twins at Simmons Field. A crowd of 4,387 attended that game{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}, producing the largest crowd of the Bob Lee-era at Simmons. However, a decline in overall attendance and higher standards for minor league baseball facilities forced Lee to sell the team after the 1991 season. New ownership moved the team to [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] after the 1992 season.
The Kenosha Kings, a local semi-pro team, also took up residence at Simmons Field in 1984. The Kings currently compete in the Wisconsin State League and won the league’s championship in 2006. The Kings are in their 25th consecutive season at the stadium, the longest run of any team during the history of the ballpark.
During the 1990s, Simmons Field was home to amateur teams of high school and college talents, as well as the Kings. The locally-run Kenosha Chiefs semi-pro team also was the stadium’s primary tenant in 1993, and the Kenosha Kroakers of the [[List of collegiate summer baseball leagues|collegiate summer]] [[Northwoods League]] called Simmons home from 1994 to 1999.
In June 1998, [[Green Bay Packers]] players also appeared at Simmons Field for a charity [[softball]] game that also drew thousands of fans. And in August 1999, chart-topping pop group [['N Sync]] also played a charity softball game at Simmons in front of roughly 2,800 fans.
In 2000, AAGPBL players returned to Simmons Field for a reunion and dozens of the former players dedicated a plaque to commemorate the AAGPBL’s time in Kenosha.
Simmons Field was home to professional baseball once more in 2003 when the [[Dubois County Dragons]] of the independent [[Frontier League]] moved and became the [[Kenosha Mammoths]]. However, the Mammoths failed to attract large crowds and the team moved again after one season in Kenosha.
In 2007 the Kenosha Parks Department leased Simmons Field to the Kenosha Unified School District (KUSD). KUSD has since leased the field to the Kenosha Simmons Baseball Organization (KSBO), a non-profit group working to upgrade and restore the stadium. Initial improvements included a rebuilt infield, which was completed in the fall of 2007, and a new electronic scoreboard behind left field.
In July 2008 the [[Men's Senior Baseball League]] (MSBL) of Kenosha organized the 2008 Women’s Hall of Fame Classic. This event hosted a large contingency of the AAGPBL players in a rededication of Simmons Field to women’s baseball. The event provided the best female baseball players in the country the opportunity to tryout for positions on the US team competing in the 2008 World Cup Games in Japan. The event was capped off with a five team international women’s baseball tournament featuring the Aussie Hearts, Chicago Pioneers, Nashua Pride, New England Red Sox and Washington Stars. The tournament was won by the Aussie Hearts coached by Kenosha native Rob Novotny.
==Current use==
Simmons Field is the home of the [[Kenosha Kingfish]], who played their first season in the summer of 2014. The Kenosha Kingfish are one of 18 teams in the [[Northwoods League]], a minor-league style collegiate, summer league of college baseball players from across the nation. The Kingfish administration renovated Historic Simmons Field in 2013. The newly renovated stadium has over 2,100 seats, obtained from [[Oriole_Park_at_Camden_Yards|Camden Yards]], contains two Home Plate Suites, a party deck, and a general admission lawn seating area.
{{NWL ballparks}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Söğütlü Athletics Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Sogutlu.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | fullname = Söğütlü Atletizm Sahası | former_names = | location = Söğütlü, [[Akçaabat]], [[Trabzon Province]], Turkey | coordinates = {{Coord|41.01650|39.59732|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 2007 | opened = 2007 | renovated = 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 7,200 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[2007 Black Sea Games]]
[[2011 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival]] | embedded = | website = }} '''Söğütlü Athletics Stadium''' ({{lang-tr|Söğütlü Atletizm Sahası}}) is a sports venue for [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] competitions in [[track and field]] located in [[Trabzon Province|Trabzon]], [[Turkey]]. It was built 2007 at Söğütlü neighborhood of [[Akçaabat]] town in Trabzon Province as a [[stadium]] with [[movable seating]] to host the [[2007 Black Sea Games|1st Black Sea Games]]. In 2011, the venue's [[bleacher|stand]]s were replaced by concrete ones with a [[seating capacity]] of 7,200, and [[floodlights (sport)|floodlight]]s were installed for the [[2011 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.trabzon2011.org/detay/4620/Sogutlu-Atletizm-Sahasi-yarislara-acildi.html |publisher=Trabzon 2011 |title=Söğütlü Atletizm Sahası yarışlara açıldı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-07-29 }} It is situated {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of Akçaabat and {{convert|11|km|mi|abbr=on}} west of Trabzon at the [[Black Sea]] coastal highway {{TUR-D|010}}. The stadium has two eight-lane tracks, one for [[warm-up]] activities. There are also two training halls, a [[health club|fitness center]] and rooms for health care, [[use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|doping]] test and press. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sogutlu Athletics Stadium}} [[Category:Sports venues in Trabzon]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] {{Turkey-sport-stub}} {{Athletics-stub}}

page.title: USA Water Polo Hall of Fame

revision.text:
The '''USA Water Polo Hall of Fame''' was established in 1976 to honor players, coaches and officials who have contributed greatly to the game of [[water polo]] in the United States of America. It was established by the USA Water Polo, which is the national governing body in the country.

{{otheruses}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = The Victoria Ground | image = [[File:Victoriaground stoke.jpg|300px]] | fullname = The Victoria Ground | nickname = The Vic | location = [[Stoke-on-Trent]] | coordinates = {{coord|52|59|57.49|N|2|10|56.96|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] | built = 1878 | opened = March 1878 | closed = May 1997 | demolished = June 1997 | seating_capacity = 56,000 (approx 25,000 before it closed) | tenants = [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] (1878–1997) | dimensions = }}
The '''Victoria Ground''' was the home ground of [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] from 1878 until 1997, when the club relocated to the [[Britannia Stadium]] after 119 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stokecity.rivals.net/default.asp?sid=944&p=2&stid=8382833|title= The Story Of The Victoria Ground|author=Gareth Cooper|date=9 June 2005|accessdate=29 June 2007|work=[[The Oatcake (Fanzine)|The Oatcake]] - oatcake.co.uk |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070508191208/http://stokecity.rivals.net/default.asp?sid=944&p=2&stid=8382833 |archivedate = 8 May 2007}}</ref> At the time of its demolition it was the oldest operational football league ground in [[the Football League]].<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City">{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=Tony|title=The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City|year=1994|publisher=Lion Press|isbn=0-9524151-0-0}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Woolwich Arsenal v. Newcastle United, April 1906.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Victoria Ground hosted seven [[FA Cup semi-finals]], one of these was this in 1906, between [[Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].]] The Victoria Ground had been Stoke City's home since March 1878 and the first match was a friendly against [[Talke]] Rangers on 28 March 1878, Stoke won 1–0 before 2,500 spectators.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> The ground took its name from the nearby Victoria Hotel and was originally an oval shape, built to accommodate a running track and used by the local athletic club.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> There was an open grass bank at each end, and a small but compact wooden stand on the east side (Boothen Road) capable of housing 1,000 people.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Opposite this stand was another bank which could hold 4,000. The ground remained this way for 30 years during which time Stoke had become members of [[the Football League]].<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Stoke suffered financial difficulties and dropped out of the league in 1908 and attendances varied during their time out.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Stoke got back into the league in 1919 and the ground had now been improved considerably. There were two good sized grandstands and an extra wooden one which was situated opposite the main stand and could hold 1,000 supporters.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>
The players changing rooms were set in the corner of the ground which also included a stove so players could keep warm.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Above the changing 'hut' was the directors box, a rather primitive building but could hold around 12 people. During the early 1920s a new, mainly wooden main stand was erected alongside the 'hut' and this could hold 2,000 fans.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> By 1930 Stoke had added 'City' to their name and the Boothen End was terraced and later covered, and consequently the ground lost its oval shape.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> 1935, when the likes of [[Stanley Matthews]] was beginning to draw in the crowds, the Butler Street Stand was built, giving seating to 5,000 people.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> In front of the seats was a small paddock, room for another 2,000 and it took the ground capacity to around the 45,000 mark.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> A record crowd of 51,380 packed into the Victoria Ground on 29 March 1937 to watch a [[Football League First Division|First Division]] match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> During [[World War II]] the Butler Street Stand was used as an army storage camp.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>
Floodlights were installed at the ground in 1956 and [[Potteries derby|local rivals]] [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] marked the 'official' switching on ceremony by playing Stoke in a friendly on 10 October 1956.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> In 1960 another new main stand was built and the dressing rooms were revamped.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> In the summer of 1963 concrete was laid on the paddock terracing and it was the Stoke players who helped lay it as part of a team bonding scheme.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> More improvements continued in the 1960s and the ground remained in a good condition until January 1976.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>
Over the weekend of the 3/4 January 1976, with Stoke playing [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] away in the [[FA Cup]], winds of hurricane force battered the [[Stoke-on-Trent]] area and especially the Victoria Ground for around eight hours. The strong winds blew a section of the roof off the Butler Street Stand leaving only the west corner intact.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Top priority was to put the roof back in order that the replay against Tottenham could take place on 7 January.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> However, on the day of the match as workmen were replacing timber supports and erecting scaffolding, some of the supports collapsed and a number of workers were injured, The match itself was cancelled on safety grounds.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> Stoke had to play one home league match against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] at [[Vale Park]] on 17 January and the Victoria Ground was reopened by 24 January in time for Stoke to play Tottenham in the cup.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>
The final improvements to the ground were made during the 1980s with the [[Stanley Matthews]] suite being opened as well as a new club shop and offices.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>
With the [[Taylor Report]] of January 1990 requiring all clubs in the top two division of English football have an all-seater stadium by August 1994, the club drew up plans to meet the requirements at the Victoria Ground, in spite of relegation to the Third Division in 1990, as the club was intent on re-establishing itself in the top two divisions - which was achieved three years later.
However, after a few years, Stoke chairman [[Peter Coates]] instead decided to move the club to a new location and so in 1997 Stoke left the Victoria Ground after 119 years for the new 28,000-seater [[Britannia Stadium]] at Trentham Lakes.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Britannia Stadium|url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/BritanniaStadium/0,,10310~71103,00.html|work=Stoke City F.C.|accessdate=19 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229154748/http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/BritanniaStadium/0%2C%2C10310~71103%2C00.html|archive-date=29 February 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
